Barcelona“The problem has turned chronic because there is no real will for dialogue on either side,” believes Juan José López Burniol, lawyer and political columnist for La Vanguardia, Catalonia’s biggest newspaper.“Catalonia certainly does not have the strength for unilateral independence&nbspbut it has a massive ability to destabilise the whole of Spain.”Polls in Catalonia confirm the ongoing stalemate, with no clear majority either in favour or against remaining in Spain.Yet while&nbspnationalist parties squabble to the point where the regional parliament was suspended for 70 days this summer because of their infighting, the Republican movement has shown no sign of losing its power to mobilise its grassroots supporters.Hundreds of thousands to join Catalonia independence rallyAround a million pro-independence supporters gathered on 11 September for Catalonia’s most important national day, the Diada, roughly the same as last year.On&nbspSunday evening across Catalonia, demonstrations were being held to commemorate the referendum.The referendum marked a watershed in political life, says Xavier Diez, a teacher and writer on Catalan modern history, “because a large number of people, even those who were not ‘independentist’, saw what happened. If you are attacked for going to vote, that affects you.”A likely start date in January for the trials of those jailed for their role in the 1 October&nbspreferendum will continue to maintain the pro-separatist parties’ momentum through the winter.“If the prisoners faced a normal series of charges for civil disobedience, rather than distorting it with charges of rebellion with violence, that would help defuse things”, believes Mr&nbspCapdevila, “firstly because they would probably be released, and secondly because calling it rebellion with violence makes an agreement much more difficult.”Catalonia elects hardline separatist as new regional presidentCurrently, though, the question of how the agenda will be moved forward on either side is much harder to see. Direct rule from Madrid, hugely unpopular in Catalonia, was ended last winter, but Mr&nbspSanchez has warned it will return if there are any attempts to move towards unilateral independence.“If I was a Spanish politician and I wanted to improve the situation in Catalonia, my career would probably be over,” adds Mr&nbspDiez.As for the Nationalists, “their big error last year was believing that in the Europe of the 21st century, Spain would not be prepared to accept the damage to its international image in return for its continuing unity,” says Mr&nbspCapdevila.Germany will not extradite Catalonia's Puigdemont on rebellion chargesCatalonia postpones vote for new headSpanish supreme court refuses to release jailed Catalan politicianThe consequences of such a longstanding, ongoing confrontation are deep isions, but even the nature of those isions are the subject of much debate.“The more urban part of Catalonia is more erse and the rural part more singularly Catalan,” says Mr Lopez, who argues that the split has been partly fostered by the separatist movement, but that “the actions of the central government, particularly the era when Mariano Rajoy led it, have caused the problem to stagnate. And that includes the social fracture.”“The fracture is only true on a political level, not in terms of day-to-day living,” counters Mr&nbspCapdevila, who says the mainly peaceful nature of the separatist question post-1 October&nbsp“should be a source of pride for independentists and nationalists alike.”“If you don’t like different political opinions, go with North Korea. Here there are two visions of how things ought to be, and that’s the same as you can find in the United States where there are two big political parties, or in Britain, with those in favour of or against Brexit.”Mr&nbspDiez cites his own family, where his sister is not pro-independence, while&nbsphe is, “in any family get-together some subjects don’t get discussed”. He adds: “In today’s Catalonia, when you don’t know somebody, you’re very careful about your words and gestures, because you don’t want to create isions.”Germany will not extradite Catalonia's Puigdemont on rebellion chargesYet at state level, dialogue between Madrid and Barcelona over Catalonia’s future remains off the table completely, a situation for which Mr&nbspLopez Burniol believes both parts to be partly responsible.He added: “They did not realise that this question only has a political solution, and that its ending up in the courts would be a serious mistake, only making the situation worse.”“And when a problem like this is approached in this way, we were always going to end up where we are now.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: theresa may conservative party conference 2018 brexit jeremy corbyn labour
story: Her government has also drawn up plans to get Britain moving, overhauling the country&rsquos damaged road network.&nbspAnd the Prime Minister has announced a new festival of Britain in 2022, which will showcase the country&rsquos &ldquodazzling array of talent.&nbspGovernment insiders denied Mrs May was reacting to the challenges of Jeremy Corbyn&rsquos Labour conference last week, saying the plans had been months in the making. But she has come under increasing pressure from nervous ex-ministers and backbenchers to take the fight to the opposition by highlighting the Government&rsquos successes and setting out a vision for the future.&nbsp                Theresa May needs to fight for social justice or Corbyn WILL WIN                 Labour MP delivers no deal Brexit car analogy which will ANGER Leavers                Councillor mocks attempted Remain 'TAKEOVER' for new Brexit vote                Labour Party in BREXIT CHAOS: 'Britons want us to GET ON with it'Meanwhile Transport Secretary Chris Grayling pledged to give drivers a smoother ride, with a major assault on bad road repairs that cause potholes.&nbspHe said: &ldquoOne of the things I will be saying in my speech later this week is that an awful lot of time is taken up in this department on rail issues.&nbsp&ldquoBut actually, we should not forget that for most people in most places it is the motor car and the roads which are the important part of their lives.&nbspMr Grayling also fears petrol prices could surge to record levels next month, as the impact of US sanctions on Iran hits the international oil rate.&nbspAnd he attacked rail unions, saying there was a &ldquoculture of militancy in the railways and the transport sector which is damaging to Britain.&nbspFormer ministers and backbench MPs want Mrs May to offer more to voters to counter Labour.&nbspEx-minister John Penrose said: &ldquoBrexit is important, but we mustn&rsquot let it blot out everything else. If we let far-Left Labour policies get hold, Britain will go backwards.&nbspLeading Brexiteer Jacob ReesMogg praised ongoing polices including plans to cut the UK&rsquos corporation tax rate to some of the lowest in the developed world.&nbspHe said: &ldquoIf we want to have a chance at winning the next election we have to deliver Brexit. But that will not be enough to win the next election.&nbspOthers warned Mrs May not to throw the baby out with the bath water and accept Labour&rsquos analysis.One said: &ldquoWe need to underline our incredible jobs and economic growth record and the fact that Labour would put that at risk.&nbspCabinet Office Minster and de facto deputy prime minister David Lidington said the Tory message got lost at the last election because &ldquowe were not getting that message across with sufficient persuasive power.&nbspHe said: &ldquoAs a party, I think we have to make again, from first principles and telling stories to illustrate it, the reasons why we believe that a free-enterprise economy is the best way to deliver both high living standards in the face of global competition and digital technology.&nbspHe added that at the same time, it should &ldquoenable inidual men and women to have greater freedom for themselves and their family.Theresa May will introduce higher duty for house buyers who do not pay tax in the UK (Image: PA)Poll lead is ideal start for partyTHE Tories have gained a three-point lead on Labour going into their conference today.&nbspDespite a well-received performance from Jeremy Corbyn at Labour&rsquos conference, his party dropped three points.&nbspThe Tories gained two, to lead 39 per cent to 36 per cent. Brexit appeared to be the iding issue for Labour supporters, with 45 per cent wanting Mr Corbyn to fight for Remain, yet 40 per cent believing the party is moving towards a soft Brexit.&nbspThe Opinium poll found that more than half (57 per cent) could not imagine Mr Corbyn as Prime Minister although his net approval rating increased.&nbspAdam Drummond, head of political polling at Opinium, said: &ldquoAlthough Liverpool was a good conference for Jeremy Corbyn, it hasn&rsquot worked for Labour overall.The Jewish community has condemned Labour leader Corbyn&rsquos 'systematic failure' to deal with anti-Semitism                    REUTERS1 of 11Jewish groups have accused Corbyn of failing to tackle anti-SemitismLoud and proud is how to winCommentary by Julia Hartley-BrewerWHY would anyone vote Tory?&nbspThat&rsquos the question that the Conservatives need to answer this week.&nbspIt&rsquos not that there aren&rsquot plenty of good reasons but, right now, the message being given to supporters can be summed up as: &ldquoWe&rsquore not Corbyn.&nbspBut that sort of negative campaigning isn&rsquot going to hack it any more.&nbspVoters will need a lot more than that if the Tories are to win the next election.&nbspLabour is winning the war of ideas because they have something to say.&nbspSo what do the Tories need to do to get voters excited about voting Conservative again?&nbspJacob Rees-Mogg speaks to the press as he arrives for the launch of a Brexit research paper (Image: DANIEL LEAL-OLIVASAFPGetty Images)Well, on her first day as PM Theresa May spoke of ending burning injustices and helping families that are &ldquojust about managing.&nbspSo why not do that?&nbspTop of the &ldquoTo Do list is to build up to two million genuinely affordable houses.&nbspThat will help families get on the ladder&nbsp&nbspand put money in their pockets to spend on our dying high streets.&nbspNext is to sort out immigration and train up young Britons to do the jobs we import workers to do.&nbspThird is to get back to basics on key issues like tackling violent crime.&nbspAnd yes, the Tories need to deliver Brexit, with no more cop-outs. Most of all, they need to offer a positive vision of why they want to govern.&nbspIf they can&rsquot do that, they don&rsquot deserve to win.&nbsp&#9679&nbspJulia Hartley-Brewer is a talkRADIO breakfast show presenter.Tried and tested way to dealCommentary by John Penrose MPTHE EU thinks that Theresa May&rsquos Chequers plan is a stinker. So far, so normal.&nbspThey were never going to agree to everything we wanted straight away.&nbspAnd the PM is quite right to ask them to come up with a few ideas of their own, instead of just criticising ours.&nbspBut we should be doing a bit of thinking of our own.&nbspWe must have alternatives, because any negotiation needs give and take. If not Chequers, then what?&nbspBritain's Labour Party Leader Jeremy Corbyn sits on stage at the annual Labour Party Conference (Image: REUTERSHannah McKay)That&rsquos where a Canada Plus plan comes in. Forget the fancy wording: the key point is the EU has agreed to pretty much all of it before.&nbspIt&rsquos a patchwork quilt of trade deals they&rsquove already signed with other countries, including Canada.&nbspSo we wouldn&rsquot be asking for anything new and it&rsquos miles better than no deal at all.&nbspDavid Davis had already developed something like this and now the trade experts at the Institute for Economic Affairs think tank have issued their version too.&nbspIt would let us sign deals with the rest of the world and give business a clear set of rules for low-friction trading with the EU after we&rsquove left.&nbspBut, most importantly, it would deliver the referendum decision itself, because we&rsquore all democrats.&nbspNegotiations are about finding common ground. That&rsquos what a Canada Plus-type deal would do.&nbsp&#9679&nbspJohn Penrose is the Prime Minister&rsquos Anticorruption Champion.

Ex-Brexit minister urges Theresa May to DITCH orce planFormer Brexit minister Steve Baker has urged Theresa May to ditch her Chequers proposal for Britain's departure from the EU.Mr Baker said the Prime Minister had wasted two years of negotiations with the EU coming up with her controversial blueprint.He said the blueprint cannot be accepted by the EU because Brussels believe it undermines the integrity of the single market.The Wycombe MP also suggested that Labour could win the next election if Mrs May continues to mishandle Brexit.Jeremy Hunt sensationally compared the EU to the Soviet Union (Image: )4.20pm: Liam Fox savages Labour and Kier StarmerTory minister Liam Fox took to the stage to aim a ruthless attack at Labour over the party's Brexit meddling.Speaking in Birmingham, he said: We are leaving the customs union and the single market despite the best efforts of Keir Starmer and the Labour Party to thwart it.We must stop re-fighting the referendum and come together to honour the diplomatic will of the British people.3.17pm: Nigel Farage should be given a peerage and put in charge of Brexit talks, says Peter BoneBrexiteer Tory MP Peter Bone told a Leave Means Leave rally in Solihull that he wanted to chuck Chequers.He suggested former Ukip leader Nigel Farage should have been made a peer and given responsibility for negotiations with Brussels: If he had been in charge, we would have been out by now.The Wellingborough MP added: I will stand up for Brexit but we need to chuck Chequers.Setting out his opposition to the EU, he said: We didn't fight world wars to be subservient. We want to make our own laws in our own country.Theresa May, seen at the Tory party conference on Sunday, faces quiet rebellion on Brexit (Image: Getty)2.52pm: Dominic Grieve warns Theresa May she faces polite rebellion over BrexitWriting in the Sunday , Dominic Grieve said opposition to the Prime Minister's Chequers plan meant a so-called People's Vote could be the only alternative to a no-deal Brexit.The former attorney general said: I believe the time has come for a polite rebellion by pragmatic Conservatives.He said it was clear that there is a significant group of Conservative MPs who think that a People's Vote- a vote on the final form Brexit will take - is absolutely indispensable for the future wellbeing of our country.Mr Grieve added: A no-deal Brexit is a proposal so damaging to our future that it cannot be accepted.So the only possible response must be to return to the British electorate and ask them what they want. That, it seems to me, is good pragmatic Conservative position.Ruth Davidson arrives with partner Jen Wilson in Birmingham for the Conservative Party conference (Image: Getty)2.22pm: Ruth Davidson arrives at the conference with her partner&nbspRuth Davidson, leader of the Scottish Conservative Party Ruth Davidson (left) and her partner Jen Wilson arrived at the Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham holding hands.Ahead of the conference, rising Tory star Ms Davidson, who is set to give birth in less than five weeks, met Mrs May, who presented her with a Downing Street baby grow.They campaign group.Placard-waving protesters massed in the city's Victoria Square on the eve of the key Tory party gathering.1.20pm Tories facing possible &pound2million fine over app data breachThe build-up to this year's conference has been marred by the breach of security that exposed MPs personal details throgh an app.It is feared the party could be hit with a fine of up to &pound2million over the breakdown, which has been branded disgraceful by one senior Conservative.The conference app can be downloaded by anyone on to their phones.It contains details such as private phone numbers, with the breach allowing anyone to log in as an MP and expose their contact details.Theresa May set for rocky reception at Conservative Party Conference (Image: Getty)12.48pm Liam Fox accuses Brussels of taunting Britain over BrexitA no-deal Brexit is not a good option and Brussels has a duty to help the UK and EU reach an agreement, Liam Fox has said.The International Trade Secretary hit out at the European Union for taunting the UK since the rejection of Theresa May's Chequers plan.Dr Fox defended the Prime Minister's leadership, which has come under intense pressure, but acknowledged he would also be prepared to serve under any successor, including her main rival Boris Johnson.He told BBC Radio 5 Live's Pienaar's Politics: I would have no problem with serving under any duly-elected leader of the Conservative Party.Theresa May has urged Conservative Party to unite and slammed unacceptable EU Brexit offer (Image: Getty)11.49am: Ruth Davidson calls on Conservative Party to back Mrs May, takes aim at Boris JohnsonThe leader of the Scottish Conservative Party, Ruth Davidson, has taken a swipe at Boris Johnson after his latest remarks criticising Theresa May.Ms Davidson called for silence in Tory ranks and urged members to back Mrs May over Brexit.Speaking on the BBC's Sunday Politics Scotland, Ms Davidson said: There's been time over the last two years for debate.The former foreign secretary was in one of the great offices of state during the time that much of this plan was being constructed - and praised it as soon ago as last year.Now is the time for Conservatives to get behind the Prime Minister, give her the space to get the deal done and to back her to deliver for the country.&nbspIn terms of a period of silence, I would be very welcoming of one.                Theresa May accuses Boris of in sharp rebuke on eve of conference                BREXIT LIVE: &lsquoDeranged and preposterous&rsquo Johnson attacks May&rsquos plan11.09am: Mrs May accuses Labour of playing politics over Brexit and demands Tory unityThe Prime Minister also accused Jeremy Corbyn's opposition of playing politics over Brexit and called for unity among Tory ranks following Bors Johnson's criticism of her Chequers' plan.Mrs May said: This is challenging for the European Union, I accept that, because it is an ambitious deal.She added: We will make a success of Brexit, regardless of the outcome of the negotiations. My message to the Labour Party is that they should stop playing politics with Brexit and start acting in the national interest.My message to my party is let's come together and get the best deal for Britain.Boris Johnson has slammed Theresa May's deranged Chequers' plan (Image: Getty)10.59am: Theresa May slams unacceptable EU offering over Brexit&nbspTheresa May has denied her Chequers&rsquo blueprint is dead in the water and vowed to face down the EU over its &ldquounacceptable Brexit stance.Speaking on BBC1&rsquos Andrew Marr show, she said: &ldquoWhat I've said to the EU is very clear.&nbsp&ldquoThey've said they have some concerns with the proposals we've put together. Let's hear what those detailed concerns are. If they have got counter-proposals, let's hear what those counter-proposals are.&ldquoWhat I'm clear on is that what we have put forward is in the national interest and we did it because what the European Union was offering us was unacceptable.She added: I&nbsp&nbspthat the plan that we have put forward is a plan that is in the national interest.This is a plan which ensures we deliver on the vote of the British people.10.40am David Davis dismisses fears over post-Brexit Northern Ireland borderMr Davis also scotched Remainers' concerns that the Northern peace process could be at risk during the Brexit negotiations.He told Sky News: Your viewers should ask themselves who do they believe on this? David Trimble in Northern Ireland - a Nobel Prize winner who put his life on the line to create the peace process - or (EU Brexit negotiator Michel) Barnier and (European Commission president Jean-Claude) Juncker?Trimble supports the arguments I have put about resolving the Irish border issue.Asked if he would support a longer transition period to sort out the Irish border issue, Mr Davis said: We don't need one. We've got 21 months coming anyway. That's way beyond what we need to do this.David Davis says Theresa May's Chequers deal will die (Image: Getty)10.33am: David Davis warns Britain in for scary few months over Brexit and Chequers will dieThe former Brexit Secretary told Sky News the EU would ramp up the pressure on Britain during the Brexit negotiations, but that Mrs May's Chequers' plan would die.Mr Davis said: I think there will be a deal. I think it is 80 to 90 percent likely there will be a deal.I think actually the deal will end up something that Boris calls Super-Canada, what somebody else calls free trade plus. Basically a free trade based deal.But, we are going to have a very scary few months, between now and about November. It is going to be really scary. Everybody is going to be calling each others bluff.10.15am:&nbspBrandon Lewis wades into Johnson row&nbspConservative chairman Brandon Lewis told BBC1's Breakfast: Boris has his own style of using language.I think the party is focused around being behind the Prime Minister to deliver a good deal for the United Kingdom as we leave the European Union.You would have to ask Boris what he thinks of the language he's using.My focus is on making sure members have a good conference and working with the Prime Minister to make sure we are delivering on the domestic agenda, on the issues that matter to people, and on Brexit making sure we get a good deal for the United Kingdom that leaves us continuing to grow as an economy in the future.10.10am: Brandon Lewis addresses the Conservative Party breach of data with its conference appMr Lewis told Sky News: Any breach of data is a serious matter and that's why we are taking it seriously. We are investigating, and we have already contacted the Information Commissioner, and will be putting in a fuller report to them.We've spoken to the company that supplied it, who themselves have put out a statement apologising for the error that they made.This will affect people where somebody has guessed or already known somebody's email address and was therefore able to log in as them. So, it will be a limited number of our delegates here and we are contacting the delegates to outline to them what has happened and what they can do about that.Asked whether he considered resigning over the app issue, Mr Lewis said: At the moment I'm focused on making sure that conference goes well.

Pressure grows on May as ex-Brexit minister says ...Mr Hunt also defended Brexit voters as he echoed Margaret Thatcher's iconic 'No, no, no' diatribe against the EU in 1990.He said: Our friends in Europe need to understand that 52 percent of the country's aren't rapid populists trying to build Fortress Britain.We fought for peace on our continent so none of us will ever turn our back on history.Of course we understand that the EU wants to, it needs to, protect itself.Jeremy Hunt said EU is becoming like the Soviet Union (Image: )The Foreign Secretary leaped to the defence of Leave voters (Image: )But if the only way to deal with the UK leaving is to try to force its break up, the answer is 'No, no, no'.It's time to&nbspshow the doubters, show the sceptics, show the world the true potential of&#8239this remarkable nation.Also speaking at the Tory conference in Birmingham, Liam Fox highlighted what he saw as the investment opportunities in the UK post-Brexit.The Cabinet minister then sounded a warning about the Labour Party, saying: Let me tell you what global investors really fear.They fear a Corbyn Labour government that would steal their investments and call it nationalisation.                Labour's Caroline Flint RIPS into colleagues backing People's Vote                Labour Party in BREXIT CHAOS: 'Britons want us to GET ON with it'Mr Hunt campaigned for Remain in the 2016 referendum (Image: )They fear the dark forces bubbling under the surface of the hard-left &ndash anti-wealth, anti-trade and anti-Semitic.A Labour Party whose leader admires Venezuela, where a hungry population, racked with hyperinflation increasingly seeks mass emigration as a solution.A party which is not the future of the young but the betrayers of the young, whose reckless spending plans would leave an economic wasteland and a generation or more of debt to be repaid.Frankly, we failed to spell that out at the last election. title: Brexit latest rees mogg tory party conference
story: Speaking to party members in Birmingham last night, Mr Rees-Mogg said the UK should not fear walking away from Brexit talks.He urged the Government to embrace the prospect of a hard Brexit by refusing to a single penny of the EU's orce bill.Mr Rees-Mogg said a move would help the least well off in Britain, and he insisted it was all legally justifiable.Outlining his plan the MP said: There is &pound40billion of your hard earned money going to the European Union which we save.                EU is the new Soviet Union! Jeremy Hunt in ASTONISHING attack                 'I'm not bluffing' Defiant May vows to DELIVER BREXIT as pressure growThere's a brilliant report by the House of Lords from March last year with a committee mainly of Remainers saying the legal position is absolutely clear.If we leave onWorld Trade Organisation (WTO) terms we are under no obligation to pay a penny &ndash not a brass farthing.We would not owe them anything and we immediately be able to trade with the world.In a crushing of Mrs May's Brexit plan, Jacob Rees-Mogg said leaving on WTO terms would be win-win for Britain.Jacob Rees-Mogg was speaking at the Tory Party Conference tonight (Image: EPA)The MP for North East Somerset said: We wouldn't have an implementation period, a transition period.We wouldn't have 21 months of vassalage where we're told what to do by the EU and have no say what is happening.Straight away we will be free to lift tariffs on goods we don't produce, improving the standard of living for those less-well off in society because those tariffs hit food, clothing and footwear.Brexit will be a success because it's a Conservative thing to be doing &ndash it's about helping people live the lives they want to live.Mr Rees-Mogg said Britain should not fear a no-deal Brexit (Image: )Mr Rees-Mogg said a move would help the least well off in Britain (Image: )He also predicted that neither Parliament or the European Union would accept Mrs May's Chequers plan for Brexit.He said: The Labour Party doesn't like it and will vote against it the&nbspConservative Party&nbspdoesn't seem to like it and we will vote against it and the EU won't accept it.The three bodies that you need to get onside will all be opposed to it, and that makes it very hard to get through Parliament.Mr Rees-Mogg, speaking at the fringe event organised by the BrexitCentral website, received a standing ovation as he left the stage.Hundreds of people gathered to hear the Eurosceptic MP at the event in Birmingham.

title: Brexit latest jacob rees mogg conservative party conference
story: Speaking at the Tory conference in Birmingham, the MP also claimed Remain would lose any future referendum if one was called.The influential backbencher said public opinion had not changed since the 2016 Brexit vote, despite the best efforts of pro-EU activists.Mr Rees-Mogg hit out at the Remain campaign demanding a second vote, saying: We should think carefully about the People's Vote.To my mind, it conjures up totalitarianism. story: Princess Eugenie and fiance Jack will marry at Windsor Castle (Image: getty)Princess Eugenie and fiance Jack Brooksbank like the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, Earl of Wessex and the Queen's eldest grandson Peter Phillips will marry in St George's Chapel, on Friday October 12.Even the Prince of Wales wed in Windsor the second time around - in a civil ceremony in the town's Guildhall, followed by a blessing in St George's.Here's a look at some of the Windsor royal weddings:- Prince Harry &amp Meghan Markle                Princess Eugenie's wedding dress CLUE: Royal slips MAJOR detail on ...                Princess Eugenie Royal Wedding: Queen to wear blue hat - bookies oddsHarry and Meghan's St George's chapel wedding on May 19 was the royal event of 2018.The US-born former Suits star wore a simple but elegant gown by Clare Waight Keller and a five metre-long veil, held in place by Queen Mary's diamond bandeau tiara, which featured flowers from all Commonwealth countries.Just a few days before the wedding Meghan's father announced he would not be giving his daughter away due to health reasons, but Charles stepped in to perform the symbolic role.Harry was given the title of the Duke of Sussex on his wedding day and his wife became the Duchess of Sussex.Thousands lined the streets of Windsor to watch the newlyweds when they went on a carriage procession through the town and the Long Walk in Windsor Great Park.The evening celebrations were staged in nearby Frogmore House where close family and friends partied the night away.Harry drove his wife to the event in a classic British sports car - an electric E-type Jaguar.- The Prince of Wales &amp Camilla Parker BowlesClarence House official handout photo of the Prince of Wales and his new bride Camilla (Image: getty)Charles finally married his former mistress Camilla Parker Bowles in 2005 after a relationship which ned decades.The ceremony was due to take place in Windsor Castle, but they were forced to switch venues to the more modest local town hall around the corner.It emerged that licensing the castle would have allowed the public to marry there too and the publicly announced original plan was hastily dropped.In the end, Charles and Camilla wed in a private, civil ceremony in Windsor's Guildhall in front of just 30 guests.                Sarah Ferguson and Prince Philip bury the hatchet at Eugenie's wedding                Sarah Ferguson embrace by the Queen ahead of Princess Eugenie wedding But the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh were not present.The monarch's position as Head of the Church of England made it difficult for her to attend a non-religious wedding.However, she did join the 800 guests who witnessed Charles and Camilla's televised, religious blessing afterwards in St George's Chapel.Camilla, who became an HRH and the Duchess of Cornwall on marriage, wore an oyster silk basket-weave dress and coat for her civil wedding and a porcelain blue silk coat and gold sweeping feathered head-dress for the blessing.Both outfits were by Robinson Valentine.The newylweds posed for photographs with the royal family afterwards on the vast west steps of St George's, just as Eugenie and Jack are certain to do.There was no carriage procession for Charles and Camilla because of sensitivity surrounding the public's reaction and the nation's affection for Charles's first wife, the late Diana, Princess of Wales.- Peter Phillips &amp Autumn KellyPeter Phillips - son of the Princess Royal - married Canadian Autumn Kelly in 2008 at St George's Chapel.Peter Phillips marries Autumn Kelly at St. George's Chapel on May 17, 2008 (Image: getty)The bride wore a gown by Sassi Holford and a tiara borrowed from her new mother-in-law, the Princess Royal.Peter's sister Zara raised eyebrows when her strapless bridesmaid's dress showed off her distinctive tan lines.Peter and Autumn left in a horse-drawn Balmoral Sociable carriage for a reception and dance at Frogmore House.- Prince Edward &amp Sophie Rhys-JonesPrince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones with their bridesmaid and pageboy (Image: getty)In 1999, Prince Edward married Sophie Rhys-Jones in St George's Chapel.Edward was given the title the Earl of Wessex on the morning of his wedding and Sophie became the Countess of Wessex on marriage.Sophie's dress by Samantha Shaw was a V-neck, hand-dyed silk organza and silk crepe design, embellished with 325,000 pearls and crystal beads and teamed with a spotted crystal detail veil.The wedding began at 5pm and men were asked to wear morning dress, but women evening dress without hats, to the continental-style evening service.There was no public kiss at the televised nuptials for Edward and Sophie, whose first kiss as a married couple took place in the privacy of the Chapel's ambulatory, where they signed the marriage register.The reception afterwards was held in the state apartments of Windsor Castle.Unlike Harry's wedding, there was no military involvement. But the couple did enjoy a carriage procession through the town.- Other Windsor royal weddingsLady Helen Windsor, the daughter of the Queen's cousin the Duke of Kent, married Timothy Taylor at St George's Chapel in 1992.There was a big royal turnout and seven-year-old Prince Harry, smartly dressed in a double-breasted blazer and tie, was a guest.Historic weddings in Windsor have included the nuptials of King Edward VII, who as the Prince of Wales married Princess Alexandra of Denmark in St George's on March 10 1863.His mother Queen Victoria was a guest.Many of Victoria's children chose to be married at Windsor, particularly during the Queen's reclusive widowhood.

title: UK weather forecast today met office latest October 2018 temperature zero degrees winter
story: It will be as low as two degrees in parts of Scotland and seven degrees in London on Monday morning (at 8am), with a maximum of just 14 degrees throughout the whole day.However, the day will start sunny in many areas of the UK and persist through the day, before the cloud patch hovering over more northern areas starts to make its way southwards.Meteorologist Helen Roberts said: &ldquoTemperature-wise, it&rsquos a little below par for this time of year, but it should feel pleasant enough in the sunshine.&ldquoSo as we head through this evening we will see clear skies in the south that will allow an early dip in temperatures.                Temperatures to PLUNGE to FREEZING as NUMBING Arctic air hits Britain                Countryfile weather CHAOS as presenter offers two forecast scenariosThe cold evening will therefore quickly descend, with sunset arriving around 6.40pm.Northern and eastern parts of Scotland and England will see some showers today.Ms Roberts said: &ldquoIt&rsquos a dry and a bright start for many of us this morning, if on the chilly side.&ldquoSome blustery showers across the northern isles and also clipping some northern and eastern parts of Scotland.Winter sun will make the drop in temperatures more pleasant (Image: WX CHARTS &amp )The winter sun will make the temperatures more pleasant, despite it feeling colder than it is (Image: )&ldquoAlso one or two showers clipping coastal fringes of England as well.The meteorologist reassured the public that sunshine will hang around for a large portion of the country, despite the cold temperatures.She added: &ldquoThat sunshine for the bulk of England and Wales will persist for much of the day.&ldquoWe will see a little bit of patchy cloud spilling in across parts of Wales, perhaps south-west England, but it shouldn&rsquot spoil the sunshine too much.                Temperatures to NOSEDIVE as ARTIC conditions BOMBARD Britain                BBC Weather forecast: 'Arctic air' to GRIP Britain this weekendTemperatures plummet to near zero in some areas (Image: Met Office)However, further north a weather system will approach the northwestern parts of the UK, spilling cloud and showers across parts of Scotland and Northern Ireland.The cloud will slowly make its way southwards, bringing the showers with it, and the north will start to clear up.The temperature will generally feel about two degrees lower than it really is.

title: BBC Weather forecast UK Carol Kirkwood news today winter temperatures this week October
story: Temperatures on Monday will remain in the low single figures but with some bright sunshine before rain and cloud move in towards the afternoon.The BBC Weather host told viewers: &ldquoWe do have the weather front coming in, bringing the rain later.&ldquoThere will be quite a brisk wind across the North and also the West.&ldquoBut down the East coast today with that North Westerly wind, it will take the edge off the temperatures.                BBC Weather forecast: Map shows close to FREEZING temperatures hit UK                BBC Weather forecast: 'Arctic air' to GRIP Britain this weekend&ldquoSo first thing for England and for Wales, it&rsquos a sunny start, but we will see the cloud develop quite quickly everywhere as we go throughout the day.&ldquoThere will be rain coming in from the North West.Temperature wise, we&rsquore a little bit below par than average this year.&ldquoIn London for example, the average would be around 17, today we&rsquore looking at up to 15.BBC Weather forecast: Carol Kirkwood told viewers to expect a chilly start to the day  (Image: BBC )Tuesday night will bring more bitter temperatures overnight, with a temperature high of just 8C across the country.Ms Kirkwood added: &ldquoAs we head on through the evening and overnight, we can see how the rain gathers and pushes South Eastwards, by the end of the night it will be getting into South West England and also Wales.&ldquoAhead of it, a few showers but it should stay dry.&ldquoBut it will be a much colder night than the one that has just gone.Throughout the rest of the week, the Met Office has predicted that gales will hit northern Scotland on Tuesday, but the rest of the country should see dry and bright weather.From Wednesday, the weather is set to be &ldquochangeable with rain in the north, but dry and sunny in the south of the UK.Temperature-wise, the Met Office predicts that it will be &ldquowarm in the south, turning cooler in the North by Friday.With colder temperatures forecast, leading bookmakers have slashed odds to 1-2 that snow will fall in the UK during October.Coral&rsquos Harry Aitkenhead said: &ldquoTemperatures are set to tumble and everything looks to be leading up to a big freeze this winter.&ldquoIt seems almost certain that at some point in October the colder temperatures will arrive and they look set to bring snow with them.

story: Japan Meterological Agency called Typhoon Trami a very strong storm.Evacuation advisories are in place for more than 3.7 million people in 19 prefectures, according to state broadcaster NHK.Western areas of Japan&rsquos main island of Honshu lie in the direct path of the storm which is now lashing its southwestern tip.Tokyo is not in the path of the category 2 storm but residents are reporting winds hitting the capital.Hundreds of flights and train services have been cancelled or suspended along with most local trains and bullet trains.Officials are urging people to avoid going outside to avoid the dangerous weather.At least 53 people were injured by Trami as it barrelled through Okinawa and Kagoshima Prefectures yesterday, according to state broadcaster NHK.More than 300,000 people there are still without power.Here are all the latest updates as they happen. title: indonesia earthquake update latest soil ground liquid liquefaction
story: The soil can be seen moving around like running water and even waves forming in what is known as liquefaction.Liquefaction happens when saturated soil loses its strength and stiffness in response to applied stress, such as the shaking from an earthquake.Twitter users have described the phenomenon as &ldquoterrifying.The earthquake also caused a tsunami that hit the island of Sulawesi, with waves as high as 6metres, according to the Indonesia Disaster Management Agency.                Indonesia tsunami: Air traffic controller gives life for passengers                Indonesia tsunami: 832 dead as 7.5 magnitude earthquake strikesMany homes, businesses and vehicles along the coast were washed away and damaged hospitals forced to shut down.Vice President Jusaf Kalla said the final death toll could be in the thousands.Many people were trapped in the rubble of buildings that collapsed in the 7.5 magnitude quake, according to Indonesia Disaster Management Agency spokesman Sutopo Purwo Nugroho.Mr Nuhroho said he estimates 2.4million people have been affected and at least 17,000 left homeless.The ground liquifies after earthquake in Indonesia (Image: Sutopo Purwo Nugroho &amp )A wave can be seen forming in the ground (Image: Sutopo Purwo Nugroho)People have been hand-digging to search for survivors in the city of Palu, which was particularly impacted.Head of the national search and rescue agency Muhammad Syaugi said: &ldquoWhat we now desperately need is heavy machinery to clear.&ldquoI have my staff on the ground, but it&rsquos impossible just to rely on their strength alone to clear this.About 50 people were known to be trapped beneath the debris of a collapsed hotel.                Indonesia tsunami: Air traffic controller gives life for passengersA man looks for his belongings amid the debris of his destroyed house in Palu (Image: )Families were seen carrying their belongings in plastic bags to outdoor shelters where thousands are seeking aid.The Red Cross are trying to get kitchens, surgical teams and mobile clinics to the region.Head of the International Red Cross delegation in Indonesia Jan Gelfand said: &ldquoPeople are afraid to go inside because of the incessant aftershocks.&ldquoCut off from the rest of the island because communications are down, people in the area are in desperate need of water, food and health care.&ldquoThere is a large, large need, and I don&rsquot think we&rsquove seen the worst of things yet.

title: Hurricane Kong rey japan Philippines upgraded storm Queenie Philippine Sea
story: Typhoon Kong-Rey is expected to hit the Philippines before following the path of Tremi to Japan.Kong-Rey currently has maximum sustained wind speeds of 130 kilometres per hour, with some more powerful gusts.It is moving in a north-westerly direction at around 15 kilometres per hour.Hurricane Kong-Rey is projected to enter the Philippines Area of Responsibility, where the Government of the Philippines is responsible for monitoring the weather, later today.                At least two people have DIED and over 120 injured in Typhoon Trami                Typhoon Trami latest: Crisis AVOIDED as Okinawa election completesIt will pass across the northern edge of the country.If it maintains its current speed it will do so between 1pm and 3pm local time (5am-7am BST).Small fishing boats have been ordered not to leave parts of northern Philippines including the islands of Batanes and Babuyan.Whilst the storm will only skirt the Philippines powerful thunderstorms could breakout across the country, including around the capital Manila.Typhoon Kong-Rey is expected to hit the Philippines before following the path of Tremi to Japan (Image: REUTERSNOAA)Kong-Rey currently has maximum sustained wind speeds of 130 kilometres per hour (Image: )Kong-Rey is expected to leave the Philippines on Friday.It will be the 17th tropical cyclone to hit the Philippines this year, with an average of 20 expected per year.In the Philippines Kong-rey will take the local name of Queenie.After passing the Philippines hurricane Kong-rey could potentially head towards Japan.                Typhoon Trami tracker LIVE updates: 3 MILLION urged to evacuate                 Typhoon Trami DAMAGE latest: Live updates as Tokyo hit by Typhoon T...Kong-Rey is expected to leave the Philippines on Friday (Image: NOAA)AccuWeather Meteorologist Rob Richards said: &ldquoTyphoon Kong-rey will travel across the Philippine Sea over the coming days and gradually strengthen.&ldquoAfter threatening the Ryukyu Islands, scenarios for Kong-rey&rsquos expected track around the start of next weekend range from the typhoon targeting Taiwan andor eastern China or curving northeastward to mainland Japan or the Korean Peninsula.Hurricane Trami battered large parts of Japan yesterday.Two people have been confirmed dead and dozens were injured.Transport links across the country were disrupted and more than 300,000 lost power.

title: philip hammond chancellor age net worth mp runnymede weybridge susan
story: From a schoolboy running church-hall discos to an Essex housing developer seizing an overlooked opportunity to make millions, heres what you need to know about Hammond...Hammond has been the Conservative MP for Runnymede and Weybridge in Surrey since 1997, and was appointed as Chancellor of the Exchequer by Theresa May on 13 July 2016, taking over from George Osborne.The 62-year-old grew up in Epping, Essex, and attended Shenfield School in Brentwood before studying Philosophy, Politics and Economics at University College, Oxford, where he moved in the same social circles as May.Journalist Andrew Gimson told Conservative Home that Hammond has long sought to guard his privacy by appearing less interesting than he really is.The dad-of-three is set to deliver his Spring statement on March 13, 2018.The Chancellor announced a review of the Apprenticeship Levy - a flagship policy of his predecessor George Osbourne.Companies previously complained the 0.5 per cent tax on their payroll costs had burdened them with more costs and restricted them from hiring more junior workers.Hammond will also plough an extra £120m to boost the number of science and high tech apprenticeships.Hammond married Susan Williams-Walker in 1991, meeting her when she was election agent for his friend and former colleague Lord Moynihan.The pair have three children - Amy, Sophie and William - and live in Send, Surrey.Susan is co-director of Castlemead and is involved in organising parties for MPs other-halves.Ms Williams-Walker has been described as glamorous and fun, with a good sense of humour, according to the Express.Friends have recalled Hammonds lovely, long silky hair, while schoolmate Richard Madeley says he was cool and popular with a breezy unconcern for what anyone else might think.Madeley says the young Tory would stroll into school with a Daily  under his arm, and revelled in political arguments with their -reading history teacher.In a blog for the Spectator, Madeley described the 15-year-old Hammond wearing a dark leather trench-coat, shoulder- black hair and square-heeled boots.He wrote: If I’d somehow intuited, as I say, that this lanky 15-year-old with the questing, beaky nose and rimless glasses, this proto-goth, would one day be Chancellor of the Exchequer...Well, actually, I wouldn’t have been remotely surprised.Hammond later laughed off the comments, and said goths hadnt been invented in those days.Another school pal Nina Stratford recalled drinking sherry with the teenager in his room before sharing a cheeky snog.Whod have thought that Philip Hammond was such a good kisser?, she told the .Despite being dubbed the ultimate boring accountant who loves spreadsheets, Hammond is a natural entrepreneur.Schoolfriends recall him making cash as a teenager by running church-hall discos, and he is said to have bought and sold cars from the nearby Ford Dagenham plant.As a student he joined a business venture to sell summer trips to the city to Iranian tourists, according to the FT, before graduating with a first and heading up several companies through the 1980s.Reports claim Hammond is the second richest serving MP with an estimated fortune of £8.2million.While he earns £134,565 from his job, his wealth comes from the housing developer Castlemead which he and pal Tony Gregson set up in 1984.The company reportedly took off after Hammond spotted an opportunity in the details of healthcare reforms, which allowed health authorities to commission new doctors surgeries.Castlemead started building doctors surgeries within its housing developments, driving turnover from £44,000 in 1994 to more than £10million a decade later, reports the Financial Times.So when the financial crisis battered the housebuilding sector after 2007, Castlemead hung on thanks to its healthcare revenues.Hammond was challenged to publish his tax s by his opposite number John McDonnell, but he refused, dismissing it as demonstration politics. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn leave betray class
story: If selling out Leave voters doesn’t bother you then yes, Michel Barnier and Martin Selmayr — the German bully running the show — will delightedly hear how you intend to achieve it.Which explains why they were so keen to give him an audience yesterday.Betrayal is very much in Corbyn’s plans, as he made clear at his conference.Not only because his party is now firmly behind a second referendum with “Remain” as one of the options.But because he is also determined to stay in the EU’s Customs Union — and thus not leave at all.So, in the unthinkable event of a Labour Government seeing Brexit through, it would do so not via tough negotiations.It would be done by immediate capitulation to Brussels’ demands that the world’s fth biggest economy remain forever under their control.We would be barred in perpetuity from signing trade deals with the faster-growing giant economies of the wider world — and the central economic case for Brexit would be destroyed.So while Corbyn now suddenly claims to care for the forgotten working-class communities who backed Leave, they must never forget this: Labour is now controlled by its middle-class London Remainer membership, all desperate to overturn or negate Brexit.WE’LL be blunt, Becks.It is repugnant to see a celebrity smugly dodge justice solely thanks to being rich enough for a fancy lawyer skilled at exploiting loopholes.Especially when that star freely admits doing 59mph in a 40 zone.Millions of ordinary people grimly suck up fines they can ill afford for far lesser speeding offences.Even  their prosecution letter arrives a day late.Beckham may be within the letter of the law, but not its spirit.That’s a bad look for a man desperate for public adulation and establishment approval.Knighthood? It’s crashed and burned.WE hope the poll revealing voters in ­marginal seats deserting the Tories over sky-high rents is enough to stir the ­Government from its paralysis.The Tories are consumed by Brexit.But away from that they must wake up and present radical ideas to beat ­Corbyn’s, especially on housing.They have an advantage.Theirs are more likely to be sane.And vanishingly less likely to put hundreds of thousands on the dole.But Theresa May must realise that voters have more pressing problems than Brexit which could cost her power.Next week the Tories must have a new story to tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: james forsyth no home comforts to ease the brexit bind
story: In the bars and on the fringe, vigorous argument will rage about what the best Brexit option is for Britain.Cabinet ministers will whisper in corridors about what the Government should do next. Boris Johnson will draw a big crowd for his “Chuck Chequers” rally.But there is a bigger danger waiting in the wings for the Tories: They simply don’t have a domestic agenda big enough for the moment.Labour has, over the past few days, set out its vision for Britain. It is, in places, scary. But give Jeremy Corbyn and Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell this, it is undoubtedly clear and bold. As one Cabinet minister says, half admiringly:  “They’re hungry.”The Tories need to show  they have a better plan, one that will deal with people’s concerns— and they don’t have any time to waste. As one minister warns: “I’m just really terried. People don’t realise what a big deal this is.”The Tory Party’s problem is that it isn’t giving the country a vision of where it wants to take it. One former party leader has taken to lamenting that the Tories have “lost the narrative”.At conference last year, Theresa May declared that it was her mission to solve the housing crisis, to restore the British dream of home ownership for the many.But in the past 12 months, the Government has made far too little progress on this. Yes, some sensible steps have been taken. But the policies that will really solve this crisis, proper planning reform and a massive, Government-led housebuilding programme, haven’t happened.The result of all this: Jeremy Corbyn gets closer to power. As this newspaper revealed yesterday, Labour is now ahead in the seats that decide general elections thanks to its massive lead among renters.The likelihood of someone in their late twenties or early thirties on an average salary owning their own home has halved in the past 20 years.This is an electoral time bomb for the Tories. They can’t expect those without capital, or any prospect of getting it, to be capitalists.By the time of the next election, the Tories need to show people that their lives are getting better AND explain the damage  Corbyn would do to the country.One minister points the finger of blame at Number 10 for the Tory predicament. “A fish rots from the head down,” he tells me. But the Cabinet can’t escape its share of the blame, either.With a few exceptions, min­isters aren’t doing enough to take on Labour’s arguments. As one former Secretary of State fumed to me during Labour conference: “It’s outrageous. Where are the Cabinet?”If the Tories get Brexit wrong, it could cost them the next election. But even  they get a decent deal, it won’t guarantee them victory. For the public will vote on domestic issues — whether the housing crisis is solved, the state of the health service and what is going on with schools.Corbyn has simple answers to all these questions: They might be wrong, but they are answers. The Tories now need to show the country  they have answers too.AT last, some positivity and optimism about this country’s post-Brexit future from the Government.I can reveal  it is planning a major new festival celebrating the UK for 2022. The aim is for this festival to tell the world a story about Britain as we leave the EU and take charge of our own future. It is meant to coincide with the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee and the Commonwealth Games, which will be held in Birmingham that year.Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright,  who is pushing this idea in Whitehall, has told colleagues  it will be: “Future-facing, telling a story about the UK’s unique strengths, particularly as a place to invest, as we forge a new future outside the European Union.”If the Government gets it right, this festival could be a great statement about the open, dynamic country that Britain is going to be after Brexit. It should emphasise how this country is going out into the world after leaving the EU, not pulling up the drawbridge.The aim should be to put on something that stands comparison with the great post-war Festival of Britain in 1951 or even the Great Exhibition of 1851, which showcased Victorian Britain’s global reach and technological edge.One Secretary of State, who is backing the idea, tells me: “People just want something really positive.”But cynics might note that there is an advantage for the Tories in a feel-good festival in an election year.But I understand he will  have a harsh message for the Westminster politicians in attendance. He will  tell them to stop bickering and positioning and get on with delivering for the country.Mr Street will say that outside the Westminster bubble, the public just want politicians to get on with things, rather than constantly jostling for position.What makes his  speech so interesting is that he is a Downing Street favourite. Indeed, I understand  some of those close to Theresa May are pushing for a similar tone in her speech.They believe  her post-Salzburg speech went down so well with the public not just because she was standing up to the EU but because she was taking charge and being that “bloody dficult woman”. They think she should use her speech to tell members  they won’t get everything  they want from the Brexit talks, but that she will get the best deal for Britain.Others, though, are wary of this approach. One Cabinet minister cautions that after last year, May should play it safe as “you can’t have two bad years  in a row”.THE Government has rightly guaranteed that the three million EU citizens living in Britain will be able to stay in the event of no deal.This is sensible. These citizens contribute a lot to this country, and help keep our economy and our public services moving.But it is also right that the Government is now discussing what the rules will be for deporting EU citizens who commit crimes after Brexit in a no-deal scenario.The details have not yet been decided and, as one government source puts it: “No one wants people deported for getting a parking ticket.”But it is right that those who are convicted of a signicant offence are removed.• SPOT the leadership bid will be one of the games  the Tories play in Birmingham.Any Cabinet minister who starts talking about their childhood will be accused of planning a run for the top job.  This leaves ministers walking a tightrope as they prepare their speeches. Some are dealing with this challenge by handing their time  to others.Penny Mordaunt, the Aid Secretary, is simply introducing a series of “British heroes” who do development work.But one of those involved in conference planning suspects that even this is about leadership as Mordaunt “doesn’t want to spend 45 minutes defending the aid budget to a hall of Tory activists”.James Forsyth is political editor of The Spectator.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady the apprentice launch slippery excuses
story: Sixteen budding entrepreneurs battling it out to win £250k of Lord Sugar’s own money as an investment to start their own business.Alan goes into partnership with the winner — and that’s where Claude Littner and I come in.We are there to make sure he chooses the right person, by watching what happens when the contestants are out on tasks.People know it’s that time of year when they see Claude and I out on the streets with a notepad, pen and film crew.We don’t mentor, we don’t coach or give any guidance, we simply watch what unfolds. And what is amazing to me is how often people try to wriggle out of things and deny a decision they made, in a bid to stay in the process. So when they sit in the boardroom saying, “I didn’t . . . ” we can say, “Oh yes you did . . . ”Some people ask me  certain scenes are staged, but the show is unique in that there are no retakes, there is no setting up of scenes and no trying to find the comedy moment — they just come naturally.All of Alan’s jokes come naturally, too. There is no script, no autocue, it happens as it happens.Luckily, we get on very well — Claude, Alan and I. So much so that we all went on holiday together this year.We’re all quite similar, we have all been married for a long time and we all share the same family values.It makes us a watertight team, although we each bring something dferent to the table.But, parking that for a moment, The Apprentice is also top-notch entertainment — this series more than ever. What’s great about the first episode is that the contestants, all of whom talk the talk about how fantastic they are, are thrown into the deep end with a task that’s designed to test their logic.They are sent on what is a bit like a treasure hunt, in Malta, armed only with a map and some euros.This task is all about logistics, negotiation and identying, and let’s say it doesn’t end well.It turns out that, unfortunately, logic is not something all the contestants are in possession of.During this series we will travel all over the country, including to Glasgow to sell emerging artists’ work to the unsuspecting public.When I say that task was more challenging than ever, I’m referring partly to the challenge of actually getting to Glasgow because it was during the storms. Remember them?Turbulence was an under-statement. On the flight there, I was gritting my teeth and grabbing on to Claude like there was no tomorrow.One thing I love about the show is that there are equal numbers of men and women, and they are on a level playing field.Let’s face it, the same cannot be said out there in the “real” world.One thing I’ve been reflecting on over the course of my time on The Apprentice is how much things have changed for women in business since I started out.When I was having my kids 22 years ago, the very notion of “work-le balance” didn’t exist. But I’m pleased to say that working women aren’t trying to Have It All any more, and the days are gone when women feel the need to keep quiet about having kids at work.Women are now more able to demand flexible working and feel entitled to have time off for, say, ante-natal classes.More “mumpreneurs” are starting their own businesses. Still, you rarely catch working mothers using childcare as a reason for being absent from work — while men, I’ve noticed, almost get points for doing so.And it is still the case that working mothers and women working flexibly are less likely to be promoted.So I don’t quite agree with Ann Widdecombe, the former Tory MP, who wrote this week that women today have “never had it so good” yet still “whinge” about inequality.Because while it might be true that things have changed for the better, most CEOs are still male.Women might never have had it so good but it’s still not good enough — and it’s not “whingeing” to point that out.HONESTLY, watching Jeremy Corbyn forgetting Labour’s six tests for a Brexit deal, when interviewed by the BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg, was like watching a hapless buffoon.No wonder he got two Es at A-level.This is the leader of the party that makes it up as it goes along – buying votes, promising everyone everything . . . and delivering absoutely nothing.As Margaret Thatcher said, The problem with socialism is that you eventually run out of other people’s money.HERE, The Apprentice star Karren picks out some highlights to look forward to during the show’s new season . . .Wyatt said: “Bill Cosby is doing great . . . Mr Cosby knows that God is watching over him . . . he knows that these are lies.“They persecuted Jesus and look what happened . . .  I’m not saying Mr Cosby is Jesus, but we know what this country has done to black men for centuries.”Just to be clear, Cosby’s conviction has nothing to do with race.The man is accused of rape and drug-facilitated sexual assault, by an astonishing 60 women . . . of all races and ages including some as young as 17.He has finally been put in prison and his victims have justice. He is a vile rapist, a violent sexual predator.His sentence is based on his crimes, not his colour.Unlike Cosby – a “disgusting sexual deviant” according to one of his victims – Jesus was innocent of the crimes laid against him.Cosby, meanwhile, has admitted to giving sedatives to young women in order to have sex with them.In short, Cosby admits his crimes, the jury find him guilty and the judge sentences him.Attempts to make this out as a racial issue are simply ridiculous.I KNOW it’s hard for men to face up to losing their hair, but someone needs to tell David Beckham that by far the best approach when it happens is . . . acceptance.But, judging from the photos of him looking a bit like a smiling Brillo pad this week that is not the route he is taking.David,  you are reading this, you are a handsome man and no one cares  you have a thick head of hair or not – please don’t turn into Shane Warne.I guess the reality star has yet to realise no one is forcing her to go out.She just needs to learn the power of saying no.In the past, I had a dreadful habit of saying yes to an engagement when I meant no, then spent days trying to think of ways to get out of it.I completely changed my le when I decided to simply things by saying yes to an invitation when I wanted to go – and no when I didn’t.IT’S hard to believe not only that West Midlands Police are allowing “thrill-seekers” to spend Halloween in a cell used by serial murderer Fred West – but that they are charging them £75 to do so.Offering this “spooky ghost hunt” at the notorious Steelhouse Lane cells in Birmingham is in very poor taste – so disrespectful of West’s victims, including his daughter who is a surviving casualty of his and is clearly still suffering every day.No doubt the relatives of those West murdered still suffer every day, too.So the fact that a stay in his old prison cell is being offered as Halloween entertainment is positively ghoulish.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brave brexit vote
story: In the largest vote ever recorded in Britain, we chose to leave the Brussels racket.And as she reveals in our exclusive interview, Theresa May is determined to tell the world that we are getting out, no s, no buts.Tory Conference this week will be testy. There remain serious splits in the party over Brexit but on one thing they must be united: nothing can imperil our exit.But while the PM is right that a second referendum is for the birds, the country is constantly holding a referendum on her leadership.On domestic issues it is Labour that seems to have an answer to everything — even  those easy solutions rely on made-up money and would be disastrous in practice.Governments cannot just promise the world in airy-fairy speeches but, faced with an Opposition full of empty promises, the Tories must be radical.They cannot just deliver watered-down versions of whatever Jeremy Corbyn has cooked up.There are plenty of brains in the Tory party. Let’s hear their ideas and a real vision of what Britain can be.IT is disgraceful that major food stores are exploiting a legal loophole to avoid showing ingredients on packaging.Teenager Natasha Ednan-Laperouse’s death should serve as a warning of how dangerous this practice is.The law states that when food is prepared onsite, ingredients labelling is not necessary. It is designed to protect small, independent stores.But our investigation today reveals large chains have not learnt from this avoidable tragedy.Pret a Manger was warned nine times about the dangers of sesame seed in its artisan baguettes and yet it continues to sell items without allergy warnings.Now Natasha’s mother Tanya has challenged the chain to lobby for a change in our labelling laws.And, hopefully, stop other parents having to suffer such a terrible loss.BON appétit, M’luds. You’re scoffing and quaffing grub and booze to the tune of £8,000 A DAY and WE’RE footing the bill.The House of Lords, which is filled with political cronies and gloried lobbyists,represents the very worst of Whitehall’s snouts-in-the-trough culture.The sooner we have an elected House with a few handpicked specialists, the better.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: indonesia earthquake palu tsunami wall of water
story: A giant wall of water raced up a funnel-shaped bay before crashing onto the city of Palu - causing utter destruction on Friday.Rescue teams now face a race against time to free people trapped in the rubble of wrecked buildings and the authorities fear the death toll could reach the “thousands”.The tsunami hit the island of Sulawesi following a 7.5 scale earthquake under the ocean.Palu lies inside a narrow bay and experts believe the shape of the coast could have concentrated the impact of the wave.Janine Krippner, a volcanologist at Concord University, told National Geographic: “That can amply wave height as it channels water into a smaller area.”The quake that led to the tsunami could have been caused when sections of the earth’s crust grinded together.However, experts are sceptical whether this alone would cause such huge waves heading towards Palu.Scientists believe landslides, above or below water, may have also contributed to the scale of the tsunami.A tsunami can travel quicker than a jet liner – meaning communities along a coastline like Sulawesis can be wiped out before they can escape.Indonesia frequently suffers earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and tsunamis due to its position on the ‘Ring of Fire’ – an arc of volcanoes and fault lines in the Pacic Basin.Many countries make up the Ring of Fire but Indonesia is seen to be the most vulnerable to natural disasters.In December 2004, a massive magnitude 9.1 earthquake off Sumatra island in western Indonesia triggered a tsunami that killed 230,000 people in a dozen countries.

title: tributes ex formula one grid girl
story: The victim, who has been named locally as 30-year-old Kate Woodcock, died when her BMW crashed into a wall near Stonnall Service Station in Walsall at around 10.20pm on Thursday.Flowers with touching messages tied to them were left at the scene where Miss Woodcock was declared dead by paramedics.Miss Woodcock had modelled for magazines, worked as a Formula One grid girl and at ious PR events, according to the Birmingham Mail.One message said: “My beautul sister, I love you so much. I am going to miss you! To  young, to  early to go, le will never be the same. Love you.”Another note, decorated with butterflies, said: “My beautul friend, I’m going to miss you so much !! Such a kind and caring person with such a happy soul.“We’ve shared lots of good times. I’m gutted your  no longer with us. I’ll never forget you. Love Emily.”A notice on a Justgiving page set up by pal Lucy Ford read: “On September 27 our lives were turned upside down when we tragically lost Kate.“Kate was a beautul special girl who will be missed deeply by everyone who knew her.A West Midlands Ambulance Service spokesman said: “On arrival ambulance staff found a car that had suffered signicant damage.“The woman driving the vehicle had suffered very serious injuries and unfortunately, there was nothing that could be done to save her and she was confirmed dead at the scene.”Two ambulances, a paramedic officer and the West Midlands CARE team were sent to the scene.Anyone who witnessed the collision, has dashcam footage or may have witnessed the black BMW Miss Woodcock was travelling in, is asked to call 101, quoting incident number 894.

title: jeremy hunt eu soviet union brexit tory party conference
story: The Foreign Secretary warned Brussels bosses are undermining the “European dream” and could end up driving other countries out with their bossy behaviour.Mr Hunt channelled Thatcher and Churchill in his crowd-pleasing party conference speech which is likely to be seen as the opening shot in a future leadership bid.The former Health Secretary voted Remain in the 2016 referendum but has since become a convert to the Brexit cause.Speaking at the party gathering in Birmingham this evening, he hit out at the EU for treating Britain badly in a bid to punish us for voting to leave.Mr Hunt said: “What happened to the confidence and ideals of the European dream? The EU was set up to protect freedom. It was the Soviet Union that stopped people leaving.“The lesson from history is clear:  you turn the EU club into a prison, the desire to get out won’t diminish, it will grow - and we won’t be the only prisoner that will want to escape.“If you reject the hand of friendship offered by our Prime Minister you turn your back on the partnership that has given Europe more security, more freedom and more opportunities than ever in history.“And a setback for the EU will become a wholly avoidable tragedy for Europe.”Quoting Margaret Thatcher, he added: “We understand the EU wants to protect itself. But  the only way to deal with the UK leaving is to try to force its  break up, as someone much more distinguished than me once said, the answer is No No No.”The Foreign Secretary - who got a standing ovation from activists and colleagues - concluded: “Never mistake British politeness for British weakness.“Because  you put a country like Britain in a corner, we dont crumble. We fight.”Mr Hunt is not the only Tory Remainer to have attacked the EU at the party conference today.Andy Street, the Mayor of the West Midlands, said: “The Spitfires which won the Battle of Britain were built at Castle Bromwich.“Today in Wolverhampton, weapons systems for the F-35 Fighter are coming off the production line.“Perhaps Donald Tusk and Emmanuel Macron should remember that, the next time they pick a fight with our Prime Minister.”Theresa May this morning called on European leaders to take a more constructive approach to Brexit talks to reduce the risk of a No Deal scenario.

title: hike speed limits motorways stop brits wasting lives on road
story: Liz Truss told a fringe event this evening that ministers should look again at moves to stop gridlock on the countrys roads.The Chief Secretary to the Treasury told a Centre for Policy Studies event on how to spend within our means: Id like us to look again at things like our speed limits on the motorway.We have often toyed with the idea of raising it to 80mph, why dont we look at that again?She claimed it would lead to “productivity improvements” because drivers would be able to get to meetings more quickly.And that they would be “wasting less of their lives” on the road.Highways England called for the speed limit to be hiked earlier this month - but said that the public wouldnt support it.It also has considered the idea of scrapping speed limits on Sundays altogether to try and ease congestion on Britains busy roads.The comments revive a seven-year-old plan by the Chancellor Philip Hammond, who wanted to boost the speed limit back when he was transport secretary.At the same event she said she was a regular shopper at chain clothes store Primark - and shes fully behind its ethos of offering customers great value for money.She also revealed she would love to see tax cuts to help the economy grow.Brexit would be a great opportunity to shake up the way we do things and make Britain fit for the 22nd century, she added.She hinted that ministers would cut legacy policies that arent working but refused to spend willy nilly and take eyes off the pile of public debt that remains.Hitting back at Jeremy Corbyns populist policies to raise taxes and go on a public spending binge, Ms Truss told Tory party activists that there was shallow support for his ideas.Jeremy Corbyn doesnt believe in freedom, she said. He believes in control.Tories need to be fair but also free, she stressed - and the party should make sure normal people have the economic freedom to control their own cash as much as possible. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
