title: tom daley reduces desert island
story: NewsTom Daley reduces Desert Island Discs listeners to tears as he recalls final moments with dying fatherLauren Laverne made an impressive TV debut as she stepped in to replace Kirsty Young on Radio 4 interview show Desert Island DiscsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAnna Slater20:14, 30 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/tom-daley-reduces-desert-island-13337962,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email It wasn't until he was dead that I finally acknowledged that he wasn't going to be there to teach me to drive, to fill up my first pint, to see me get married, to see me have a kid.   Those were Olympic bronze medallist Tom Daley's heartfelt words as he spoke with candour about his dad Robert's death on BBC Radio 4's Desert Island Discs today.  He bought the show's listeners to tears as he told Lauren Laverne, who was standing in for Kirsty Young, how he felt in intimate detail. He was just 17 when he lost his dad, a year before his success as a er in the Olympics.  Tom explained how he was called back from Fort Lauderdale, Florida, by his mother when she knew his father had a few days to live. I get home and I see my dad in a hospital bed in the living room, he said. As the days went by his condition started to deteriorate. And, you know, one of the last things he said to me was: 'Do we have our tickets yet?' I thought, 'Tickets for what?' And he said: 'Those London 2012 tickets, because I want to be right on the front row.' And I was like, 'Oh my goodness', because I didn't know how to say to him 'You're not going to be around to be on the front row, Dad.'  Lauren handled the heart-to-heart with sensitivity as he continued. It was the next day, when all of our family and friends were around and he had gone unconscious. We were watching his chest, he said. I was holding his hand as he stopped breathing.  It wasn't until he stopped breathing and he was dead that I finally acknowledged that he wasn't invincible, that he wasn't going to be there to teach me to drive, to fill up my first pint, to be able to watch me win an Olympic medal, to see me get married, to see me have a kid. All those things. Because 40 years old is such a young age to die. I was 17, my brother was 15 and my younger brother was 12. You know, that's such a young age to lose a parent and a big, big adjustment to not have your biggest cheerleader with you any more.

title: two new suspects ira birmingham
story: NewsTwo new suspects in IRA Birmingham pub bombings of 1974 to be named in documentaryExplosion, originally attributed to Birmingham Six, killed 21 and injured 1982 — and a documentary is set to identy suspects for the first timeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMirror00:01, 1 OCT 2018NewsMichael Patrick Reilly, pictured in the 1970s, is one of the two Birmingham pub bombings suspects named in a documentary"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo men are today named as prime suspects in the IRA pub bombings in Birmingham, which killed 21 people and left 182 injured. In a special documentary to be broadcast this evening, Michael Patrick Reilly and James Francis Gavin are identied as allegedly being involved in the attacks. Reilly has never before been publicly named as a suspect, while Gavin has been connected, but not as one of those suspected of planting devices. Reilly has denied any involvement. Evidence uncovered in the new probe implicates both as allegedly having key roles in the 1974 atrocity, when two bombs exploded in crowded pubs in the city centre. The blasts at the Mulberry Bush and the Tavern In the Town were among the deadliest of the Troubles.  Six men – known as the Birmingham Six – had their convictions quashed in 1991 after 16 years in prison.  They had always insisted they were beaten and signed false confessions. No one has since been brought to justice.  In tonight’s ITV Exposure programme, court documents reveal Reilly – a member of the Birmingham IRA cell – was questioned about the pub attacks in the 1970s. But it never emerged as Reilly was charged in connection with six unrelated bombings and conspiracy. He pleaded guilty to four of the seven charges and got ten years. The ITV team looked at material in the National Archives and interviewed officers from the original inquiry. Bill Squires, a former detective inspector for West Midlands Police anti-terror squad, originally arrested Reilly in 1975 as a suspected IRA member. “I thought he’d done something serious,” Squires told the programme. “And that he was happy to make admissions and accept a sentence because there was more serious matters in the locker.”  Confronted recently in Belfast by ITV’s John Ware, Reilly denied planting the bombs, or knowing the bombings were going to take place. He did not comment on being a member of the IRA or the allegation he was the unnamed man who previously admitted involvement to ITV’s World in Action. “I’ve got nothing to say,” he said. “Well, you can ask what you want, but I’m not going to answer. You’re wasting your time.” James Gavin died in 2002. In 1977, he murdered a suspected IRA informant and was sentenced to le. It comes as the Court of Appeal has ruled a new inquest into the attacks will not consider the identity of the bombers. But relatives are still desperate for answers.

title: uk weather forecast brits enjoy
story: NewsUK weather forecast: Warm weather to RETURN after temperatures drop below FREEZINGIn parts of the country temperatures could reach 21C again by midweek with sunny spells, forecasters sayShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBrett GibbonsDanya BazaraaNews Reporter08:59, 1 OCT 2018Updated09:22, 1 OCT 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/high-pressure-raise-temperatures-after-13339026,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Brits are set to bask in a warm weather once more after temperatures dropped to below freezing in parts of the country.  Overnight, the lowest temperature recorded was -1.7C in Eskdalemuir, Scotland, while it was -1.7C at Kielder Castle, Northumberland.  A few places dipped to under 0C, the Met Office said, but conditions should improve amid sunshine today and over the course of the week.  And despite a chilly start to the week, by Wednesday and Thursday temperatures will even be slightly above average.  High pressure will be in charge for much of the rest of the week bringing balmy weather for large swathes of Britain, while staying cloudy most of the time, the Weather Channel says. The best of the warmth will be in the south-east where the mercury could reach 21C by midweek. There is a risk of some sharp showers in the north-west where low pressure and associated cold fronts brush the fringes of Scotland, forecasters say.  But generally for the rest of the UK, there will be some mild days with brightest weather in the north and spells of drizzle possible further south. Winds will be stronger in northern areas of Scotland with a chance of gale force gusts, but it should stay calmer in southern regions and the Midlands. A spokesperson for The Weather Channel said: “It will be mostly dry with a mixture of cloud and bright, or sunny, spells under higher pressure extending eastwards from the Atlantic. “Temperatures will be around normal and above normal in the south and nearing 20C although there could be some rain for the North Sea coasts.”

title: as it happens dundee united v ross county
story: Cries of &#8216Csaba out&#8217 rang around Tannadice as United slumped to an embarrassing defeatShambolic, abject, and abysmal are all words that can be used to describe Dundee United&#8217s performance as they were humiliated on their own patch by Ross County.The Terrors were hopeless at the back and pretty blunt going forward as the Staggies romped to all three points. It is hard to defend United manager Csaba Laszlo now and it would be no surprise  he is given his jotters after this most horric of days.It started when eventual hat-trick hero and former Tangerine Billy Mckay opened the scoring from close range on 11 minutes, knocking in a Josh Mullin cross.The only chink of light in the game came six minutes later as Pavol Safranko got on the end of Fraser Aird&#8217s delivery to guide the ball past Scott Fox in the away net.From there United laboured and County took advantage. Scoring the most simple and avoidable goals &#8211 often carbon copies of each other.The second came on 29 minutes after a Jamie Robson mistake played in Mullin to square for Mckay to knock in.On 41 minutes the same problems United had faced all game down their left-hand side were there for all to see as Sean Kelly inswinging free-kick went all the way through past Matej Rakovan in the home net. A horrible goal to concede with no communication evident and the defence at sixes and sevens.Soon after the restart the Staggies put the game to bed when Mullin and Mckay linked up again with the former this time tapping in from a yard out on 50 minutes.Mullin turned provider, once more, two minutes later laying Mckay&#8217s hat-trick on a plate for him and the Northern Irishman gobbled it up from a matter of inches out.Csaba tried to change things for the Tangerines, but by this point the punters had seen enough and were leaving in their droves and calling for his head in the process, as he brought on Stewart Murdoch and Fraser Fyvie to try to change things on 56 minutes.And three minutes later Murdoch summed up the Terrors afternoon as he was shown a straight red for a stamp on Jamie Lindsay.It capped what was United&#8217s worst performance in years as County saw out the rest of the game with little problem. Is it time up for Csaba?Full details in live blog.&nbsp

title: blether sandy davie returned to dundee united after his stint at southampton
story: Former Dundee United goalkeeper Sandy Davie has featured in this column on quite a number of occasions.We even cleared up the big debate as to why he was in a team photo with Dundee’s championship-winning team of 1961-62.A cutting, dated May 16, 1972, revealed his  for a second stint as a Dundee United player. It read:Sandy Davie is back at Tannadice Park.Last night, team manager Jim McLean completed a transfer deal for the big goalkeeper, an ex-Scotland U/23 cap.It’s three-and-a-half years since Davie  left United for Luton Town for a transfer fee of £8,000.He then joined Southampton two years later.The circle was completed yesterday when Sandy ed for his second spell with United.There was no fee involved.After the transfer, Davie, now 27, said: “I can hardly believe this.“The move came right out of the blue.“I’ve been hoping to get away from Southampton for some time, simply because of the consistency of Eric Martin  gave me little chance of a first-team place.“In my term there, I played just four games for the league side.“But the transfer deadline came and passed, and so did the end of the season.“I thought my chances of an early transfer were slender.“Even at that, I never dreamed that Dundee United would come for me again.”Sandy is married with two young sons.He’ll sell his Southampton house and move north as soon as possible.He’ll be a very valuable member of the Tannadice pool. A point stressed by Jim McLean.Said the boss: “With Donald Mackay away, I need another experienced goalkeeper to join Hamish McAlpine. “Sandy Davie fits the bill.”When Davie left Tannadice, McAlpine was the No 3 keeper, just beginning to challenge Davie and Mackay.McLean also announced that Davie will go on tour with United to Nigeria next week — provided all formalities can be completed in time.Soon after signing, Davie was on the receiving end of ‘jags’ for the trip.It means that 17 Tannadice players will now be making the tour, and it’s an ideal opportunity for Davie to get into the swing of things.On leaving Tannadice for a second time a year later, he emigrated to New Zealand, and played for North Shore United, Mount Wellington and Napier City Rovers.Davie was also capped for New Zealand on 11 occasions.

title: blether this is when east fife previously scored six goals away from home
story: Each week, BwB gives a sample from the Readers’ Queries file in the old Sporting Post.SP Query – On April 20, 1991, ‘Edinburgh East Fe Fan’ asked: Prior to the recent 6-3 win over Alloa, when was the last time East Fe scored six goals away?SP answer – You’ve had to wait over 27 years. East Fe beat Brechin City 6-0 at Glebe Park on January 18, 1964. Scorers were Meechan 2, Dewar 2, McWatt, McLevy .In fact, it’s just under 20 years since the Fers scored six goals at home. On that occasion, they beat East Stirling 6-2 on March 20, 1971 – the year they won promotion to the top ision. Scorers were Hughes 2, Clarke, Finlayson, Honeyman, Quinn.

title: bus drivers from national express hq in birmingham drafted in to help dundee shortage
story: Drivers from the Midlands are being brought to Dundee to try to ease the city’s bus crisis.The Tele understands that five bus drivers from Birmingham arrived in the city this week to drive Xplore Dundee buses.A spokeswoman for the transport company has confirmed that they are being brought in to ease the problems caused by a shortage of drivers.She said: “National Express has centres in Dundee, the West Midlands and Coventry.“It makes sense for us to use bus drivers from these other centres while we have a shortage in Dundee.“We are doing everything we can to ease the disruption to bus services which we are currently facing.”However, the spokeswoman declined to confirm how many drivers had arrived in the city from south of the border.She added: “We maintain our stance that we are working hard, using what measures we can to resolve the immediate issues.”Last week, the Tele reported that dozens of bus cancellations had occurred in Dundee in the last few weeks, causing inconvenience for local commuters.North East councillor Brian Gordon said that his constituency had been particularly badly hit, with 30 services cut over two days last week.He said: “I welcome the fact that Xplore are doing something to deal with this.“However, there are two issues with the English drivers.“One is that they don’t know the routes in Dundee and they’re not going to learn them overnight.“Secondly,  it is just five drivers then that isn’t enough.“Many bus drivers in Dundee are complaining that they are missing out signicantly on holiday days due to them because of the shortage.“Five extra drivers isn’t going to resolve this.”

title: csaba happy to be able to call on quality as dundee united prepare for ross county
story: Boss Csaba Laszlo will be pleased to be able to turn to his bench for support as his Dundee United side host Ross County at Tannadice.Csaba will welcome club captain Fraser Fyvie back to the fold after he missed last Saturday’s 2-0 win over Falkirk due to him not being risked on the articial surface so soon after recovering from a knee injury.He will be joined in the matchday party by winger Billy King as a few other absentees fight back to contention.“With these players coming back it will create more competition and up the quality in training,” Csaba said.“Sam Stanton and Stewart Murdoch are back in training with the team, while Nicky Clark will need another week.“It is important to get these players back to speed.”On Fyvie, Csaba added: “It was a frustration to have a player that can’t play.“We also have to accept that he is a player who has been injured long-term.“It has not just been an easy injury that takes a little time to recover from.“Psychologically, you must also be ready for this kind of match.“As a manager, you have to accept it when a player says ‘This isn’t the best game for me, on the articial pitch’.“For that reason he didn’t play but he will be OK for the Ross County match.”One player Csaba has, sadly, ruled out for the forseeable future is Lewis Toshney.“He has been out for a year so it is not easy for him.“He is fighting to come back.“I am happy that he can train but I don’t think we can talk just now about the first team.”

title: dundee gaffer neil mccann hoping lengthy injury list eases for crunch hamilton clash
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann is hoping his walking wounded recover in time for today’s vital Premiership game against Hamilton kicks off.The Dens gaffer is under pressure to arrest his side’s run of straight defeats – six in the league, seven in all competitions – as the Dark Blues head to Lanarkshire to take on Accies.Martin Canning’s men sit on six points and can move nine clear of their relegation rivals with a second win in two, after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren last week.Neil will have at least one addition to his options after winger Roarie Deacon declared himself available for action.After a y period out, caused by an injury to his ankle picked up in the last game of last season against Partick which required surgery, it’s likely the former Arsenal man will have to settle for a place on the bench.Last week’s 3-0 defeat to Hibs saw Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all limp off.Finnish striker Kallman’s problem was cramp and won’t keep him out today while Madianga and Miller’s injuries were muscle based and it remains to be seen how long they may be out for.The club are hopeful Josh Meekings will be back fit after a thigh injury picked up against Motherwell four weeks ago.He missed the defeat to Hibs, though, Neil may be tempted to stick with his two loan signings Andy Boyle and Ryan Inniss in any case.At the top end of the field, the Dens boss will be hoping targetman Sofien Moussa has recovered from his knock picked up before the loss to Hibs to give him another option in attack.Meanwhile, Kenny Miller will serve the final game of his two-match suspension today.

title: dundee incinerator pollution exceeds targets due to incinerator reliance
story: Dundee is sending above-average amounts of carbon emissions into the atmosphere as a result of its reliance on incinerating waste.Data published by the Scottish Environment Protection Agency  shows Dundee generated 64,297 tonnes of waste in 2017.Of that, 4,017 tonnes  was sent to landfill, while 58.3% was erted away and fed into the incinerator at Baldovie Industrial Estate.However, incinerating waste creates pollutants which rise up into the atmosphere, meaning recycling is still considered the preferred option.The city created 154,000 tonnes of carbon emissions in 2017, but, Falkirk, which generated 10,000 tonnes more waste in the same period, created 5,000 fewer tonnes of carbon emissions.Perth and Kinross also generated 10,000 tonnes more waste than Dundee last year – but emitted 14,000 fewer tonnes of gases.As a result of its reliance on incineration and ersion from landfill, Dundee’s recycling efforts also lag behind national targets.The city currently recycles 35.5% of its waste, up from 33.6% in 2016. The Scottish Government wants 70% of waste to be recycled by 2025.Neighbourhood services convener Kevin Cordell said he was “pleased” to see recycling on the up – but conceded more had to be done.He added: “The council is continuing to work hard to implement services to all residents for recycling collection.”

title: dundee united sack manager csaba laszlo
story: Dundee United have parted company with manager Csaba Laszlo following yesterday&#8217s 5-1 home thumping by Ross CountyThe club and Csaba have mutually agreed to end his contract effective today, with No 2 Laurie Ellis taking over on an interim basis.Dundee United chairman Mike Martin said: &#8220I would like to thank Csaba for the considerable commitment he showed during his time at Dundee United and for his contribution to improving the underpinning football structure at the club.&#8220We wish him all the best for the future. I can also confirm that Laurie Ellis has taken interim management responsibility for the team.&#8221Ellis will likely be in the dugout for Saturday&#8217s trip to face Ayr United in the Ladbrokes Championship as the Terrors look to appoint a replacement for Csaba.The Hungarian took up the post himself on November 8 last year and leaves the Tangerines sitting fourth in the table and five points behind leaders Ayr.&nbsp

title: exclusive argentina legend claudio caniggia to return to dundee
story: Dundee fans haven’t had much to cheer recently but they will be given a lt with news Claudio Caniggia is set to make a  to the city.The 50-times capped Argentine international – and former strike-partner of Diego Maradona – will be back in Dundee at the Whitehall Theatre on Thursday November 29.Caniggia will be joined on stage by renowned Dundee-supporting journalists Patrick Barclay and Alan Patullo, to discuss his World Cup heroics, that goal against Brazil, his time in Italian football, being offered the chance to  to the national team at 43 years of age, and, of course, his time with the Dark Blues.His arrival at Dens Park 18 years ago, stunned Scottish football and attracted international media attention.Although 33-years-old when he signed for Ivano Bonetti’s Dundee in September 2000, a debut goal at Pittodrie proved there was no doubt that he would still be a star in the Scottish game.Despite being at Dens for less than a season, Caniggia remains idolised by the Dundee supporters and was inducted in to the Club’s Hall of Fame in 2009.The evening will be hosted by broadcaster David Tanner.During his time at Dens, Caniggia wore the No 33 shirt each time he played. Accordingly, tickets for the event are priced at £33.Tickets – including a limited number of VIP Meet &amp Greet briefs – are on sale from 9am tomorrow morning by logging on to thelongestforty.&nbspHelp For Kids are the event charity partner, with a donation being made to the charity for the benefit of local children, and tickets being made available for families who might not have otherwise been able to attend.

story: Caretaker boss Laurie Ellis is set to be given the chance to show he’s the man to lead Dundee United on a permanent basis.The Tangerines’ assistant boss has been put in interim charge following yesterday’s sacking of Csaba Laszlo.He’s expected to lead the team into Saturday’s clash with Championship leaders Ayr United at Somerset Park.And the 38-year-old could be given more games to show he should have the job on a permanent basis. 100vw, 576px" /Get today&#8217s Tele for more on this story.&nbsp

title: hamilton boss martin canning wont be shed a tear for under pressure dundee counterpart neil mccann
story: Hamilton boss Martin Canning insists he cannot afford to take any notice of Neil McCann’s plight ahead of Saturday’s clash with bottom side Dundee.Pressure is piling on the Dens Park manager after six straight Ladbrokes Premiership defeats and a Betfred Cup exit to Ayr United.However, Canning noted his side beat St Mirren 3-0 at home on Saturday for their first win in four matches, to give Accies some respite of their own.He said: “You’ve got to go and do your own job and my job on Saturday is to try to get Hamilton Accies three points and  we can do that we’ll be delighted.“That’s just football. We know Dundee will be desperate for the points.“We’ve got to make sure we match that and that gives us the best opportunity.“We’re all going to have spells when things don’t go our way.“I’m pretty sure, same as I do, he’ll believe in his players that they can go and win games and he’ll work hard to try to make that happen.“One result can make you feel a lot better.“I think at times last season, half-a-dozen clubs went through runs of losing four, five, six games and it can happen in this league quite easily.“I thought Dundee were good against St Mirren – very good.“The goalkeeper makes a mistake and they lose the game and from there it snowballs into a poor run of results, so it can happen so easily.“The flip side of it is, you go and win two or three games in a row and it’s a completely dferent complexion.”

title: local youth groups to share 40k cash pot
story: A total of 15 youth-related projects chosen by young people in Angus will receive a share of £40,000.Twelve of the 15 will be fully funded from The Power of Youth award, which was made available by Angus Council as part of its commitment to participatory budgeting and in celebration of the Year of Young People 2018.The youth-focused fund was ided into four, offering £10,000 for groups in each of the county’s locality areas – Carnoustie, Monieth and Sidlaw Arbroath Brechin and Montrose and Forfar and Kirriemuir.Successful applications, and the cash award they will receive as a result of 1127 young people aged from S1 to 18 years old voting, were announced by the strategic director for people, Mark Armstrong, at Angus House.He also congratulated everyone who was involved in the 35 bids that were made for the funding.A spokesman said: “Bids received totalled £91,082.57, meaning that not all of them could be accepted.&nbsp

title: neil mccann urges his dundee players to give themselves an easier ride
story: Neil McCann has urged his players to “give themselves an easier ride” at Hamilton on Saturday as they search for a first result of the campaign.The Dark Blues have endured a woeful start to the Premiership season, losing their opening six fixtures and scoring just twice.At the start of that run was also a 3-0 home defeat in the Betfred Cup to Ayr United, making it seven defeats on the trot.In none of those matches have Dundee managed to put themselves in front and their gaffer is desperate for the players to at least give themselves a chance of picking up a result.In order to do that, they’ll have to get the better of an Accies side high on confidence after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren in match that has had a bit of extra spice over the past few years.And despite extra pressure on him to get the result, Neil still has faith in his side.He said: “It’s a huge game, they always have been against Hamilton.“The games against Livingston, Hamilton, Kilmarnock are going to be so important and then Hibs and Hearts.“We are still striving for that first win and we’ll keep trying to give everything to get ourselves that first goal that can at least put ourselves in a position to go and get that first win.“I still think that you could see in the first 45 minutes last Saturday, there is a team there.“I would just love to see them give themselves an easier ride by putting themselves in front.”The Dens gaffer is also hopeful of having some extra bodies back fit after a punishing injury-hit spell.Josh Meekings, Genseric Kusunga, Nathan Ralph and Sofien Moussa all missed the defeat to Hibs with injury while Kenny Miller was suspended.He’ll also miss Saturday’s trip to Hamilton while Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all added to the injury worries last weekend.The good news is winger Roarie Deacon is nearing a  after getting 45 minutes under his belt in a bounce game this week.Neil added: “We’ve not had an easy run of it and it’s been tough to get a settled side out.“We had Glen Kamara and Ryan Inniss back from injury lay-offs on Saturday but it’s been problematic in terms of that.“I have been happy with the squad,  I can get them all fit it would be welcome but we’ve not been able to get that.”

title: something to be proud of majority back dundees new va
story: It has been branded by some as a waste of money and a blot on Dundee’s landscape.But it appears the majority of locals are happy with the city’s new £80 million V&ampA museum.An exclusive online poll by the Evening  has revealed more than 80% of our readers have either already paid a visit to the attraction or plan on doing so soon – about 40% each.Just 18% said they didn’t plan on visiting the V&ampA at all.A total of 444 people responded to our survey featuring a series of questions about people’s early perceptions of the museum of design.Nearly two-thirds of those who took part in the poll said they were happy with the public money that had been used to build and run the attraction.Respondent Stan Riley defended the spending, insisting the benefits “will be reaped many times over” by future generations.Paul McFadyen, from Menzieshill, added: “The money for the project was invested over a decade. I would actually say the museum is good value for money  anything.”Just 7% were “not fussed” about the spend while 32% said they would like to have seen the cash invested elsewhere.Reader Mark Petrie said he felt it would be years before the city knows for certain whether it was worth the money while Alison Donald wrote: “Meantime, what is happening to the people of Dundee using foodbanks?”We asked people to rate the V&ampA from one to 10, based on what they’d seen of the museum so far.A total of 179 people – 40% – gave it full marks, with another 11% giving it nine out of 10 and 10% rating it as eight out of 10.Tele reader Dave Alexander wrote: “I love it, for once we have something to be proud of in our city. Work in progress, I say.”Mike Swan added: “Heck of a lot better than what was there before. Don’t knock it, enjoy it.”Just 49 people, 11% of those who responded, said they’d give it one out of 10, with the other placings spread between 2%-6%.We asked readers to tell us what their favourite part of V&ampA Dundee was. The most popular was the museum’s appearance from the outside, which was top of the list for 170 people – 38% of respondents. 100vw, 620px" /Nearly 30% said the permanent exhibitions, including Charles Rennie Mackintosh’s iconic Oak Room, was their favourite part.A total of 58 people – 13% – voted for the temporary Ocean Liners exhibition while nine folk said the cafe or restaurant was their favourite. Just 79 people said they didn’t like any part.We also asked readers to identy the biggest benefit to Dundee of having the museum. More than 40% said they felt the indirect jobs the museum would bring to the city, through attracting investment from other companies, was the biggest pluspoint.Lisa Lawrence wrote: “It will give confidence to businesses looking to move to the city.“Growth has to start somewhere so why not with this investment in a great city?”A further 22% said they believed V&ampA Dundee had improved the way the city looked, though just 5% felt the biggest benefit would be educating people in design and the arts.A further 6% felt the jobs created by the museum itself was the biggest thing to celebrate.Just 18% of people said they felt the V&ampA would bring no benefits to Dundee.A sceptical Ian McGhee wrote: “In a couple of years one or two of those new hotels will be closed as there are too many of them, and the V&ampA will be used for local kids as a school trip. There won’t be demand for hotels long-term.”

title: we are not manchester city csaba explains why he feels being dundee united boss is the hardest job in scottish football
story: There were some cursory glances around the Press room at the Falkirk Stadium after Dundee United’s 2-0 win on Saturday when boss Csaba Laszlo, almost out of nowhere, asserted the following.“The most dficult job in the Scottish Championship, or Scottish football at the moment, is to be the manager of Dundee United.”He qualied that statement by adding that it is also dficult for his players to pull on the black and tangerine but his remarks did pique the interests of those gathered.It wasn’t so much disagreement or astonishment that filled the room but more a sense of being taken aback by the brutal honesty of a man who has been under such pressure of late.He eased some of the weight on his shoulders with the result at Falkirk under what were strange circumstances – namely going up against predecessor Ray McKinnon in the opposite dugout for a side sitting bottom and pointless.And it was clear that, despite assertions by some that Csaba is daft or clueless, he was very aware of the ramications had he not got the right result.“We showed good team spirit under pressure, they handled it positively,” Csaba commented as he laid out his case to the gathered press.“Now we can close this chapter and look ahead to the next game which will be very dficult.“This is the third season where the fans have been disappointed to be in the second tier and we are talking about a very massive, strong and passionate club that wants to be in Premiership.“If something doesn’t go right immediately you have noise which is OK but we don’t want to hide behind anything.“We have this pressure and we have to accept.“We don’t want to spend one more year in the Championship – it’s not good.“The Dundee United fans don’t want to hear that from the board, the manager or anybody. They want to have the target of promotion and winning the league.“This is pressure, this is normal but you have to understand we have a budget that isn’t any higher than other teams in the main.“You have to bring a team together. We had 19 players leave and 16 players come in for the new season.“We can’t click our fingers and have the team work fantastically.“There are rules at the club about how many or which kind of players we can bring in within our budget.“It is not easy, we are not Manchester City with an owner behind you who can give you £20 million to go and spend.“We have to work with the budget we have to get the best for the club.“The Dundee United board have done a fantastic job. It is not easy to convince players from abroad to come to the Scottish Championship with everything else around.”It was quite a defence – but probably one that was coming after weeks of trying to keep a lid on it following poor results against Alloa and Morton.Yes, he has not had his troubles to seek with injury and scrutiny from all angles but it seems to be just the beginning for Csaba in his most tough of jobs.In the next four weeks they take on title rivals Ross County, Ayr United, Partick Thistle and Inverness. They kick off that run at home to County on Saturday.“I don’t just look at one game being more important than the other because you can’t afford to take any game lightly,” Csaba added. “You have to take every opponent seriously, whether they be at the top, middle or bottom of the league.”

title: Blainie 9 defies the odds in charity race
story: &nbsp&nbspIn 2016, Blainie White  was diagnosed with a form of Batten disease which affects just eight people in the UK. It is a neurological condition which causes gradual loss of sight and movement, leaving the schoolgirl wheelchair-bound.The condition also causes Blainie to suffer from epilepsy.However, a team of dedicated family and friends have rallied round to raise money for specialist equipment which could transform her quality of le, and helped Blainie complete the Baxters River Ness 5KM race last Sunday.Her proud dad Scott  said: &ldquoThere was a full squad of us out doing the run and that was fantastic. It was really good for Blainie to be able to do it.&ldquoShe was really enjoying all the noise and the music. You would never have thought that she would be able to do it, but she did.&ldquoWe have raised nearly &pound700 just through doing the run, which is brilliant.The family are raising money for a flotation device which will allow Blainie to swim, as well as a robust wheelchair to help her enjoy the great outdoors.&ldquoShe just loves going in the pool, Mr White said.&ldquoHowever, it' between &pound700 and &pound800 for a device.&ldquoWe are also looking at getting another wheelchair as well because we need one that' a bit bigger for when she' outside school.&ldquoWe are always out doing walks which is another reason we need a more robust wheelchair for her.&ldquoGetting out and about in the fresh air is something she really enjoys, but it also helps with her condition because it tires her out.&ldquoSleep is so important because  she doesn&rsquot get enough, that heightens the seizures.Blainie' cause is also being championed by the Royal Bank of Scotland, where three relatives work.The bank' staff in Inverness have picked the Batten Disease Family Association as their chosen charity for next year.&ldquoRBS have taken BDFA on as their charity of the year which is absolutely fantastic, Mr White added.&ldquoMy partner Laura and her sister both work at the bank and her other sister is the manager so I just kept pestering them. Every year they have a charity they pick and for them to pick the BDFA is brilliant.&ldquoAny money RBS raised will be doubled by the bank as well which is a huge bonus for us We are really grateful.Mr White says his daughter continues to inspire the family on a daily basis.&ldquoShe can&rsquot walk or talk any more, but she is always laughing and giggling, he said.&ldquoShe does get a lot out of le. She' an inspiration to us all.- To donate to Blainie' fund, visit justgiving/crowdfunding/littlebeesbattleMonday 1 Oct 2018 10:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Entrance to Victorian Market to get facelift
story: WORK&nbspcould begin on the Victorian Market' makeover as early as January.Highland Council has submitted planning applications to improve the appearance of the Academy Street entrance to the complex, which dates back to 1869.The plans involve bringing the glazed screen closer to the street in order to improve visibility into the market.The local authority says this will make the site more accessible, as well as improving security by reducing the number of access points on Academy Street to one.An uplighting system is also set to be installed in order to highlight the historic architecture of the building, and signage will be removed to &ldquo historic integrity to the Academy Street facade.The project marks the first stage of an action plan, which is being implemented by the council and the Inverness Common Good Fund, which is also set to build a business case for the remodelling of the market hall.No timescale for the completion of the work has yet been finalised, but an application for a grant of &pound30,250 has been submitted to the Inverness Townscape Heritage project.The news of the redevelopment came just days after traders in the Queensgate Arcade section of the market spoke of their struggle to deal with ongoing issues with the complex roof.Businesses in the privately-owned section of the building have been forced to take action to deal with repeated leaks which have at times forced them to close.Toni Rutherford, of the Little Teapot cafe, believes businesses in the market need help to deal with the problem.&ldquoIt is really frustrating for us that this problem keeps reappearing, she said.&ldquoIt' not good, especially when you walk into the arcade and see all the buckets.&ldquoIt' not a good impression for customers.&ldquoWe understand that there will be issues with the age of the building but that' all the more reason to take care of it, especially  people are wanting to make all these improvements to the building.&ldquoThree quarters of the building is owned by the council but the section we are in is privately owned.&ldquoThat means that any issues with the roof in our section have to be dealt with by us as traders.&ldquoThere have been times where we have had to close because of it. We have had waterfalls coming into the tearoom while customers have been in.&ldquoAlthough dferent sections of the building are owned by dferent people we are all under one roof, so we feel there should be some help available for the situation.&ldquoEveryone in the building needs to come together to get the problem solved.Monday 1 Oct 2018 10:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Gay pride march to go ahead
story: &nbspA gay pride march through the centre of Inverness has been given the go-ahead.Proud Ness, which will take place on October 6, has been at the centre of a bitter row after Donald Morrison, a home mission worker with the Free Church of Scotland , submitted a petition to Highland Council signed by 600 people opposing the event on "biblical, religious and moral grounds".In response, thousands of supporters signed counter petitions, saying gay pride was celebrated all over the world and the people of Inverness wanted to be on the right side of history.The council confirmed this morning the march can go ahead."We have notied the organisers that Highland Council and Police Scotland have no objections to the march being held as per the details in their notice of intention," the spokeswoman said.Previously, the spokeswoman said the petitions from both sides would not have a bearing on the decision process as the raised matters of concern were not sufficient reason to refuse the parade.Monday 1 Oct 2018 10:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Horror over plan for hundreds of trucks to pass Inverness school
story: &nbsp&nbspThe six-month operation, which is due to begin next spring, would take the lorries via Cloverfield Road, the southern distributor route, B8082 and onto the A9.Contractor, forestry management company Scottish Woodlands, has told Highland Council it has reached agreement with a neighbouring farmer for a track to be upgraded to give lorries access to the woods.But local community figures say that does not address the issue of public safety.The firm says the work at Balvonie Woods is essential.Inverness South councillor Ken Gowans said: &ldquoThis involves 480 truck journeys. To put that size of truck through a residential area, past Inshes Primary, is an unacceptable risk not to mention the disruption that could cause to the community. Some of the school community were horried at the prospect.Inverness South Community council secretary Bob Roberts said: &ldquoNo matter what they do the lorries will pose problems.&ldquoI&rsquom very concerned for the pupils&rsquo safety because as well as this, at certain times of day the parking around the school is horrendous.The community council is still to formulate its official response to Highland Council.Scottish Woodlands&rsquo regional development manager Bruce Taylor said: &ldquoIt' quite early days. There&rsquoll be a consultation period from now until the end of the year and we&rsquoll look at all options.&ldquo The point is to raise the proposal into the public arena and get responses with an expectation that we would be attending community council meetings to discuss the matter.&ldquoAt the end of the day, the wood is becoming unsafe because there is wind-throw in it and we need to find a solution to it because the owner is becoming concerned that at some point somebody might get hurt by a fallen tree.Dates are still to be arranged for consultation events.Monday 1 Oct 2018 10:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Just get on with it Eastgate Hostel owners told
story: &nbsp&nbspPat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, said the owners should &ldquostart now and stop making excuses after they said they were &ldquofocusing 100 per cent on moving forward with plans to finally tackle the eyesore.Owners Imtaiz Ali and a Mr Cheng recently said they hoped a contract for demolition could be in place before the end of November, but work may not start until after the festive period to avoid inconveniencing neighbouring traders.In answer to further questions posed to them by the Courier, through agent Gary Johnston of GH Johnston Building Consultants, they also revealed more about their plans for the shop spaces and two holiday apartments set to be created when the building is restored.&ldquoMr Cheng intends to reinstate his quality food takeaway restaurant, Mr Johnston said.&ldquoThe other shop unit will be available for rent as a class one shop, restaurant, hot food takeaway or other business considered suitable in the town centre. This may require a further planning application to Highland Council.&ldquoThe holiday apartments are aimed at visitors to Inverness and the Highlands and are commensurate with similar holiday lets in the High Street.&ldquoAs the apartments will be new and with a generous floor area, they will be at the higher end of the quality lets.They owners said they would take &ldquosoundings from Inverness Business Improvement District in terms of when would be the best time to start demolition work and refused to discuss why it had taken more than 2000 days to get anything done.Mr Johnston said: &ldquoThe owners will not make any comment on the past as they are now focusing 100 per cent on moving forward to get the scaffolding off the street and starting on the rebuild.But Mrs Hayden said she wanted to see action as soon as possible and there had been enough talk in the city about moving things forward.&ldquoStart now and don&rsquot use Christmas as an excuse. Get [the scaffolding] down. Today' a lovely day to start, she said.&ldquoWe&rsquove had enough excuses &ndash I&rsquom fed up of excuses.She said that when the fire happened her grand-daughter had been an infant, adding: &ldquoThat grand-daughter is about to be seven. That puts it in perspective &ndash it' been far too long.&ldquoAction is what is needed. Never mind consulting everybody &ndash everyone in that area wants rid of the scaffolding.&ldquoDon&rsquot wait until after Christmas because then the weather will be bad and then there&rsquoll be another excuse.Monday 1 Oct 2018 10:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Pensioner pleads for help with poorly cat
story: &nbspAn Inverness pensioner is appealing for help with her cat' medical treatment after discovering that her monthly pet plan does not cover the cost of an X-ray.Marie MacIver' five-year-old cat Charlie has a painful leg and needs the scan to determine what treatment can be given.However, Mrs MacIver, who relies on disability benefit, is unable to afford the X-ray, which will cost about &pound300.She has now contacted the&nbspmedia in a plea for kind-hearted Invernessians to come forward."There is no way I can afford to pay for the X-ray," she said."Since it' very dficult for me to get out, I have already had to pay for the vet to come to the house and give Charlie a medical, as well as a bottle of anti-inflammatories which cost &pound29 and did nothing."I already pay &pound10 a month for a pet plan but it doesn&rsquot seem to cover anything."I have tried everywhere to get help with the vet' bills &ndash the PDSA, RSPCA and Cats Protection, but I haven&rsquot been able to get help from anywhere."I hate to see him in pain and I think it' getting worse."It came out of the blue about a month ago, and now it is just not going away."Mrs MacIver lives alone with Charlie and says she has a special bond with her little cat."He' my companion and is often the only company I have," she said."He sleeps on my bed and follows me into the kitchen, and he seems to know not to stray too far from the house because I need him."He' really more like a dog than a cat."I try my best to take care of him but things like this are very dficult, and it is such a shame because he is a lovely little cat."I need to help Charlie get better."&nbspCan you help Mrs MacIver with the cost of Charlie' X-ray? Email us via newsdesk@spp-groupMonday 1 Oct 2018 10:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Pressure on Highland Council to stub out unethical investments
story: HIGHLAND Council could review its stake-holding in tobacco, alcohol and weapons companies.Opposition to such selections was spelled out by Ross-shire councillor Angela MacLean amid long running anger about the ethics of the local authority investing millions of pounds in such industries while also claiming to promote &ldquohealthy lestyles through council policies.Over the past 15 years, a small band of councillors has registered opposition to widely perceived &ldquounethical investments but to no effect.Independent fund managers are employed to get the maximum . Recent figures showed the fund increased in value in 2016-17 by &pound31.1 million. As of last weekend, it was valued at &pound2,013,164,722.61.Addressing colleagues on the audit and scrutiny committee, Cllr MacLean called for a review of investment strategy. She acknowledged the need to secure the best .But she added: &ldquoSome people are not happy with some of the investments and feel that perhaps  it' invested in tobacco or arms or things like that, it' not ethically responsible.She asked whether fund trustees had any say in the choice of investments.The council' investments change on a daily basis.Recent examples of contentious choices include British American Tobacco , liqueurs firm Pernod Ricard , pubs chain Mitchells and Butlers , Japan Tobacco  and China' second largest brewery, Tsingtao .The council' finance director Derek Yule explained that an investments sub-committee reports to a pension board which sets the strategy.&ldquoIt is very dficult when some of the investment strategy seeks to invest in shares in companies not just in the UK but worldwide, he said.&ldquoWhilst I totally understand some of the ethical debate, it is very dficult to draw a line sometimes.&ldquoYou might take a view&hellip would you invest in banks, for example? They might not be the best investment, anyway. But I use that as an example because banks will fund these companies.&ldquoIt' a dficult balancing act but it' certainly within your rights  you wished the pension board to look at the investment strategy.&ldquoFund managers are given guidelines to work to, so that would be quite legitimate for the council to do through the pension board.According to current policy, the fund &ldquorecognises that social, environmental and ethical considerations are among factors investment managers will take into account, where relevant, when selecting investments for purchase, retention or sale.However, it stresses that &ldquothe overriding consideration for pension committee members is their fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and scheme members.The Scheme Advisory Board, established up by the Scottish Government to regulate such public sector pension funds, recently obtained advice from legal counsel on the duty of pensions committees.The guidance concluded that: &ldquoPensions committees in Scotland owe a fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and the scheme members in general and specically in relation to investment matters.&ldquoThose duties should be exercised in the best interests of the beneficiaries and in relation to investment decisions, should aim to achieve the best financial position for the fund, balancing risk and  in the usual way.Monday 1 Oct 2018 10:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Response to Charlie tale stuns cat owner
story: &nbsp&nbspMarie MacIver, who lives in Hilton and relies on disability benefit, lives alone with her five-year-old cat Charlie.She got in touch with the Courier after it became apparent that Charlie' injured leg needed an X-ray, which she could not afford.She had already contacted animal welfare charities without success.After we printed the story last week, we were inundated with offers of help for little Charlie &ndash and Mrs MacIver admitted she was moved to tears.&ldquoI don&rsquot know what I would have done without everyone who offered to help, she said.&ldquoI&rsquove been in tears because people have been so nice. I had a card from a lady wishing me and Charlie all the best. That was such a touching thing for someone to do.&ldquoThe card has pride of place on my mantelpiece.&ldquoPeople are just so kind, even to a poor little animal like Charlie.&ldquoSome people would see him as just a cat but to me he is much more than that.&ldquoI just want to say thank you so much to everyone who has been in touch wanting to help. I didn&rsquot think anything would come of it.Local cat owner Ian Aird came to Mrs MacIver' aid, donating enough money to cover the cost of the X-ray, leaving her gobsmacked.&ldquoI can&rsquot thank Ian enough, she said.&ldquoIt was so kind of him to do that for me and Charlie.&ldquoI&rsquom so incredibly grateful to Ian. I have no words that can describe how grateful I am for what he has done.Mr Aird said: &ldquoI am a cat owner myself and when I read the story I felt so much sympathy for Mrs MacIver.&ldquoShe is an elderly lady and she doesn&rsquot get out of the house very much so that' why I thought it was important that I helped her.&ldquoFor someone in her position, Charlie is often her only companion.&ldquoThis situation seems to have resonated with a lot of people, particularly cat owners around Inverness.Charlie has now been diagnosed with patellar dysplasia, where the kneecap is slightly misshapen, and requires no further treatment other than keeping weight off his leg.&ldquoI&rsquom so relieved it' nothing serious, Mrs MacIver added.&ldquoBut I have taken out an insurance plan, and I would encourage everyone else to do the same in case something like this happens again.Monday 1 Oct 2018 10:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Star honour for city cadet
story: &nbsp&nbspEuan Stewart from 1st Battalion the Highlanders&rsquo Inverness detachment has been appointed the battalion' new Cadet Regimental Sergeant Major .The 17-year-old who joined the youth organisation five years ago is being championed for his long list of achievements.Graeme Wells from the army cadet force said the high flying cadet has climbed right up the ranks to completed his Master Cadet, which is the highest a cadet can reach.On top of his cadet achievements he has also had the honour of being the Lord Lieutenant' Cadet of Inverness-shire.This position allowed him to assist the Lord Lieutenant of Inverness-shire, Donald Cameron of Lochiel, in his duties as Her Majesty The Queen' appointed representative for the area.Mr Wells said Mr Stewart was also an &ldquoexcellent shooter who has represented the battalion on several occasions in regional and national shooting competitions, including the Inter-Service Cadet Rle meeting at Bisley Ranges in Surrey.Last year he scooped the battalion its first trophy in this contest, coming in first in the Patriotic 500 competition.Mr Wells added: &ldquoEuan was promoted to his new position at Fort George last Saturday while taking part in training for the upcoming Scottish Cadet Military Skills Competition in which he has been named as the team' Section Commander.Mr Stewart, who is a Culloden Academy pupil and has his heart set on studying mechanical engineering at university, said he was delighted with the honour.He said: &ldquoMy brother Andrew was originally in the cadets and he achieved a high level so that inspired me and we also have connections with the Honorary Colonel Councillor Carolyn Caddick whose son was the last RSM so and I guess I was quite inspired by him too.Monday 1 Oct 2018 10:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: World of work goes back to school in Inverness
story: &nbsp&nbspThe event &ndash which was supported by Highlands and Islands Airport Limited , Skills Development Scotland and Developing the Young Workforce  Inverness &amp Central Highland &ndash involved organisations across a wide range of sectors, including healthcare, education, construction, hospitality, tourism, science and technology, finance, creative industries and emergency services..The pupils also had the chance to work on their CVs, discover workplace expectations and practice their interview skills.Head teacher John Rutter said: &ldquoWe consistently have high positive destination figures for our school leavers and events such as this really complement the year-round hard work that all our staff put into giving our young people the best possible chances for success.For the first time, the event also included a mini trade show, giving pupils the chance to mingle with the more than 40 businesses attending.Andy Maxtone, programme manager for DYW Inverness &amp Central Highland, said: &ldquoInitiatives like the employability event are great for pupils, as it opens their eyes to the dferent types of jobs out there, and the ious paths that can be taken to attain them.Monday 1 Oct 2018 10:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: aberdeen edged out 1 0 by celtic at parkhead
story: Aberdeen failed to secure back to back wins at Parkhead for the first time since 2004 as they lost 1-0 to Celtic.The Dons faced Celtic bidding to rack up another away win over the defending Premiership champions having triumphed 1-0 at Parkhead in the final game of last season.The pressure was on Celtic boss Brendan Rodgers following the defending champions worst start to a league campaign in 20 years.However the Hoops grabbed the three points courtesy of an improvised back-heeled goal from substitute Scott Sinclair in the second half.Aberdeen made two changes to the side which edged past Hibs 6-5 on penalties in a draining League Cup quarter-final clash at Easter Road on Tuesday evening.Striker Stevie May ed to the starting line up with Sam Cosgrove dropping to the bench.Northern International winger Niall McGinn also ed ahead of loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe.Celtic created the first opportunity in the second minute following a swt passing move that culminated in a  Mikael Lustig cut back to James Forrest but the Scotland cap&#8217ss curling 15 yard shot flashed wide.The Dons threatened on the quarter hour mark when a corner kick swung in from the left was cleared as far as Gary Mackay-Steven at the edge of the box but the winger sliced his shot well wide.It was a cautious start from both sides who were showing mutual respect.Mackay-Steven was becoming increasingly influential on the left flank and burst down the wing in the 19th minute before crossing towards the far edge of the penalty area.McGinn raced in to meet Mackay-Steven&#8217s delivery but  drilled a powerful 20 yard drive just wide.Moments later McGinn crossed into the box and it just agonisingly alluded the unmarked James Wilson eight yards in front of goal.Celtic were denied by the woodwork in the 25th minute when a curling effort from Odsonne Edouard from 25 yards beat ing keeper Joe Lewis only to crack off the far post.Aberdeen came close with a superb attack when Mackay-Steven drove at goal and stepped past two challenges inside the penalty box to open up a shooting opportunity.Keeper Craig Gordon somehow pushed it behind.From the resultant corner Andy Considine, who netted in the 1-0 win in May, rose to power in a header that beat Gordon but Leigh Grfiths was on the line to kick clear.In the 48th minute Dons keeper Lewis pushed a low drive from Callum McGregor wide for a corner.On loan Manchester United striker James Wilson fired in a superb 25 yard curling effort from the right only to be denied by Gordon&#8217s ing save in the 52nd minute.Wilson was to come off on the hour mark to be replaced by Sam Cosgrove.Celtic went ahead in the 63rd minute when a ball from James Forrest into the box took a deflection that sent it spinning up into the box.Substitute Scott SINCLAIR used real improvisation and awareness to back-heel the ball into the net from six yards.It came at a time when Celtic were becoming increasingly frustrated and Aberdeen influential.In the 73rd minute Grfiths&#8217 shot a free-kick wide of the defensive wall but keeper Lewis got down to block.The Dons should have equalized in the 75th minute when Mackay-Steven whipped in an intelligent free-kick towards the onrushing Mikey Devlin but with the goal beckoning the defender volleyed it wide.Deep into injury time Grfiths broke upfield and clearly pulled on the jersey of Devlin to gain an advantage. The referee waved play on and Grfiths raced upfield only to miss when chipping over the advancing Lewis.Aberdeen: Lewis, Logan, Shinnie, Considine, McKenna, Wilson, McGinn, Mackay-Steven, May, Devlin, Ball.Subs: Cosgrove , Lowe , Anderson Subs not used: Cerny, Forrester, Gleeson, Campbell.Celtic: Gordon, Hendry, Brown, Grfiths, Boyata, Ntcham, Edouard, Lustig, McGregor, Forrest, Tierney.Subs: Sinclair , Rogic , Morgan .Subs not used: Bain,  Gamboa,  Christie,  Mulumbu.Referee: Bobby Madden

title: sign our petition to change time of aberdeen semi final clash at hampden3
story: Dons fans have branded the decision to make Aberdeen’s League Cup semi-final against Rangers at Hampden a noon kick-off “an absolute disgrace”.Supporters’ groups, the club and Hearts have all hit out after it was revealed both semi-finals would be played at the national stadium in Glasgow on the same day.And now the Evening Express has launched a petition in an effort to make the SPFL reconsider the ridiculous scheduling of the Aberdeen v Rangers League Cup semi-final on Sunday October 28.The lunchtime kick-off is an outrageous time for fans from the north-east to get to Hampden – and scheduling the Hearts v Celtic semi on the same day at the same venue only compounds the problem.Sign this petition to send a message to the SPFL that’s loud and clear: This showpiece fixture MUST be changed to a new venue or time for the sake of the fans.

title: wolves interested in dons defender mckenna reports
story: English Premier League side Wolverhampton Wanderers are reportedly interested in Aberdeen&#8217s Scott McKenna.The Scotland international has played in the Dons&#8217 last three matches after recovering from a hamstring injury suffered against Rangers on August 5.Scouts from the Molineux club are believed to have taken in the Reds&#8217 1-0 win over Motherwell on Saturday week.If the Midlands outfit wish to sign McKenna, 21, in the January transfer window they will have to play top dollar as he is under contract until the summer of 2023.During the summer transfer window Aberdeen threw out bids from Celtic and Aston Villa for the stopper.

title: aberdeen girl abis boxing clever for achievements in sport
story: Abi Allan has already shown success in her sport – despite being only 12 years old.The S2 Bridge of Don Academy pupil competes in kickboxing, and has been extremely successful.She is shortlisted for the physical achievement award, which is part of the Children and Young People’s Services Awards which aim to recognise the achievements of young people through sport.She was nominated by head teacher at Bridge of Don Academy Daphne McWilliam.Abi was selected to be part of the Team GB squad in the +47kg category, and placed third in the World Championships which were held in Budapest in May – facing stf competition from some of the top competitors in the world.She is the current British and Scottish WAKO champion in her weight category, and was crowned Open Weight champion in January 2018. She is also the current Scottish World Kickboxing Association champion in the -46kg category.Mrs McWilliam said: “Abi trains almost every night for a couple of hours and is focused and determined to achieve the best she can. This is on top of her education.“Her goal is to,  it becomes an Olympic Sport, represent Team GB at the 2028 Los Angeles Olympic Games.“She spends a lot of time travelling to competitions and training events, taking her away from her friends after school and at weekends.“But nevertheless, she is so determined and focused she does not see this as an issue and has very supportive friends around her.“She plays her achievements down and does not look for praise, she is very sincere and grounded. It is great to have her as a pupil at Bridge of Don Academy.”The talented youngster was surprised to find out she had been nominated, after Mrs McWilliam surprised her with the news.Abi said: “I was really surprised, I didn’t know I had been nominated but I was pleased. I train four times a week but I’m about to go on holiday to Disneyworld in Florida for a rest so I’m excited for that.”

title: aberdeen out of school club praised by inspectors
story: An Aberdeen out of school club has been lavished with praise in a recent report.Great Western OOSC @ Holburn West was given the highest possible mark following an unannounced inspection.The Care Inspectorate awarded the club excellent in the quality of care and support and the quality of management and leadership.One parent told inspectors their children are “very happy there, therefore we in turn are happy with their care”.Inspectors last reviewed the city centre club in 2015, where it was awarded two good and two very good grades.The report said: “We saw her display excellent leadership skills and role modelling throughout the inspection.“Any concerns raised by parents or incidents that arose at the club were fully explored with a clear focus on supporting the best possible outcomes for the children and working in partnership with parents.”

title: aberdeen woman hopes messages spread a touch of happiness in community
story: An Aberdeen woman is spreading positive messages around a community hoping to “brighten someone’s day” and help those who “suffer in silence” with mental illness.Jessica Nicol has tagged Cove with 24 uplting and affirmative written messages.The 25-year-old, who owns a crafts and gt shop, was inspired after someone unexpectedly sent her a positive message about her work.“Someone messaged me a few months ago and I thought it was a really nice gesture,” she said.“They wrote me an uplting message and I thought it was so positive.“If their message made me feel the way it did – why not do it for others? I decided to do something similar – something nice and simple that didn’t cost anything.“I decided to put them around Cove .“It’s meant to brighten someone’s day or maybe someone who finds it can hand it to another friend.”Jessica and her younger sister Amber O’Brien worked their way around the area to distribute the cards.She said: “She’s always on hand with anything I need help with, whether it be my work or help with my son.“I wouldn’t have, or couldn’t have, done it  I didn’t have her help.”The pair started at Cove Harbour before making their way through Old Cove, the Altens Community Centre and finished at the GP surgery.Jessica also hopes it can help people who might “suffer in silence”.She said: “A lot of people suffer with anxiety and depression and there’s still a lot of stigma surrounding mental health.“There’s a lot of people out there suffering in silence and I hope they can help someone who finds them or even someone can pass it on to someone who might need to hear something positive.“I don’t think one card will fix everyone’s problems, but one card, especially for somebody going through a dficult time, could help them feel better for a bit.”The mother-of-one takes her inspiration from the positive quotes she sees on social media and tries to put those messages on the cards.“I’m all about a positive mind and positive thinking.“People who follow me on social media know I’m always posting quotes about reminding yourself that you are beautul and confident.”Since Jessica planted the messages around Cove, people have reacted positively on social media and she is considering continuing the project.“At first, I wasn’t sure I should share what I was doing – I didn’t want it to be about the publicity,” she said.“But after a while, people started finding the cards and asking what they were about.“My sister told me ‘You should let people know why you’re doing this’.“The other day I drove through Cove and I noticed that a few of them were already gone.“It makes me feel amazing to know that there’s people out there picking them up.“I’ve seen posts on social media that said they found a card and that it brightened their day.”

title: survey 99 on board for skate park
story: Nearly 100% of respondents to a study have thrown their weight behind skate park plans.As part of a feasibility study, 99% of people said they would be happy for the skate park to be built in Banchory.The group behind the plans was given the green light in May to seek a lease for the land at Bellfield Park by the Marr Area Committee.Due to the nature of the land, Banchory Skatepark Group  would need to gain a lease from a sherf before starting to build.BSG was tasked with producing a feasibility study as part of the application to the sherf.Russ Crichton, chairman of the BSG, said: “The feasibility study covered many areas but of particular interest was the community consultation.“The consultation threw up a fantastic result and very supportive comments.“Overall there were 531 responses with 99.3% support to a new skate park in Banchory.“We are now completing the specication to issue out to Public Contracts Scotland to gather bids for the new skate park.“We are also continuing to develop the design and preparation for our planning application which will take place in the next few weeks.”The consultation asked respondents 17 questions about the skate park, covering topics from the local need for the development to the possibility of a fee being charged for use.If the fee were to be introduced, the report says, it may only be applicable at night, and will primarily be used to fund a “pay as you go” floodlight system.Respondents decided £3 per hour was a fair price to charge for the lighting.Almost three-quarters  of respondents said that floodlighting should be part of the facility.The cost of the project is estimated at £240,000, 25% of which will be matched by the Banchory Developers Fund.

title: letters to the editor week 34
story: Colin CameronUpdated: 26/08/18, 9:00 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Sir,The decision of Argyll and Bute Council to allow expansion of Poll na Gille and BDNC Loch Shuna is reprehensible.These sites have been named as being the first and third worst respectively of all the salmon farms in Scotland on an index of welfare and health measures, including premature death rates, sea lice numbers, escapes, breaches of biomass limits and seal shooting .Despite the above, there was a decision made by Argyll and Bute planning department that Environmental Impact Assessments were not required for the expansion of either of these fish farms.The Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform committee report on the environmental impacts of salmon farming stated, in a letter dated March 5, 2018, to the Rural Economy and Connectivity committee that: &#8216The committee is supportive of aquaculture, but further development and expansion must be on the basis of a precautionary approach and must be based on resolving the environmental problems.  The status quo is not an option.&#8217It is apparent that Argyll and Bute Council does not intend to adopt the precautionary approach recommended, but continues to agree to unsustainable expansion, even at locations which are in breach of the current standards required.Christine Richards, Friends of the Sound of JuraSir,We would like to invite your more adventurous readers to join us on our Lake District challenge next spring and help save lives and rebuild futures shattered by meningitis.They will conquer eight peaks, all above 3,000 feet, over two days. It will require energy, commitment and a positive attitude, but will reward those taking part with breath-taking views, wrapped up in a serious adventure and a weekend they’ll never forget – there’s a great team spirit amongst those taking part and many come away from the challenge having made lelong friends.Every step they take will also help us to fight meningitis and move us closer to our vision of a future where no one in the UK dies from this devastating disease and everyone affected gets the support they need.Registration is just £49, with a fundraising pledge of £500. Accommodation, food, travel and the support of a qualied and experienced mountain leader and safety team are all included, and I&#8217ll be there to support you throughout your fundraising journey. It takes place between Thursday May 2 and Sunday May 5 next year.Find out more at www.MeningitisNow.org or by emailing me at michaelai@meningitisnow.org .Michaela Ifill, Meningitis NowSir,The World&#8217s Biggest Coffee Morning event is fast approaching and we would love for readers in Argyll and Bute to get involved.Having become a national institution since it launched in 1990, it has raised millions to help change the lives of people living with cancer, including here in Argyll and Bute.Last year some 200,000 people said that they were planning on taking part in homes, workplaces and schools across the country &#8211 but the idea remains as simple as ever: come together as a community in support of people living with cancer and raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support.Cancer can affect every aspect of a person’s le, from their day-to-day living and relationships to their finances and mental health. Macmillan is there to help people with cancer live le as fully as they can.Offering a broad range of cancer information and support services &#8211 including a free support line and a community of over 7,700 healthcare professionals &#8211 demand for Macmillan’s services is constantly growing, but we rely on the generosity of the public to provide this support.Macmillan’s Coffee Morning takes place on Friday September 28 &#8211 but people can host whenever they want. Whoever they invite and whatever they serve, people are highly encouraged to host a Macmillan Coffee Morning in a way that suits them.If people can’t bake, that doesn’t have to stop them. Throughout September, headline partner M&ampS will be selling a selection of limited edition coffee morning products &#8211 including lots of cakes, biscuits and two exclusive mugs &#8211 with 10 per cent of proceeds going to Macmillan.Homes, workplaces and communities from the Shetland Islands to Land’s End will be hosting coffee mornings this year readers in Argyll and Bute can find events nearby using the interactive map on the Coffee Morning website www.macmillan.org.uk/coffee.Thank you to everyone who gets involved.Joanna Lumley, actress and Macmillan supporterSir,The SNP announced it is starting up a new &#8216fact-checking&#8217 service to monitor the accuracy of research and political statements.Many people in Scotland will be wondering  the SNP will be fact-checking the cost of its new independence blueprint. Analysis has continually shown that an independent Scotland would mean cuts to public spending and increased taxes.The SNP now has to answer serious questions about the real cost of independence as the latest GERS figures will once again show how much we benefit from being part of the UK. It&#8217s time for the separatists to be honest and accept the facts.With Labour embroiled in a new scandal almost every second day and the LibDems disappearing into irrelevance it&#8217s clear that only Ruth Davidson&#8217s Scottish Conservatives can stand up to Nicola Sturgeon&#8217s IndyRef2 obsession.Cllr Alastair Redman, Isle of Islay&nbsp

title: science matters week 36
story: Colin CameronUpdated: 09/09/18, 9:01 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.The multi-million dollar international trade in exotic pets has long been a bugbear of mine.Not only does it promote wild animals as  fashion accessories, but it also allows potentially dangerous microbes to jump to, and cause epidemics in, other species including humans. What’s more, even  they don’t mutate as occurred in the case outlined here,  released into the wild either by design or mistake these foreigners can cause havoc to local ecosystems.In a letter to the scientic journal Nature in 2003, a group of German scientists began ‘it has been rumoured that an unidentied crayfish…of marbled appearance and uncertain geographical origin that was introduced into the German aquarium trade in the mid 1990s, is capable of unisexual reproduction ’.The authors ended by warning that: ‘This crayfish…could become a menace to European freshwater systems, as the release of even one specimen into the wild would be enough to found a population that might out-compete native crayfish’.Now, 23 years later, this all-female crayfish has escaped into the wild.  Identied as a descendent of the fresh water slough crayfish from Florida, it is now called the marbled crayfish or Marmokrebs. So far it has invaded the waterways of at least nine European countries as well as Japan and Madagascar. Unravelling its origin reveals that a unique macro-mutation must have occurred in a single slough crayfish egg probably caused by heat or cold shock whilst in transit from Florida to Germany for the pet market.The resulting female hatchling possessed three sets of chromosomes per cell  and the ability to produce clones of itself without a mate and at very high frequency.Because of its warm climate and abundant freshwater habitats, Madagascar has seen the most rapid colonisation with Marmokrebs. Millions of the animals have invaded the countries lakes, rice paddies and swamps and are threatening its seven endemic crayfish species.It is only a matter of time before this scenario is repeated in other locations, destroying valuable ecosystems and eliminating indigenous species.

title: some close shaves in the strc
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated: 10/09/18, 9:00 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Subscribe NowThere were only two Mid Argyll crews competing in the Scottish Tarmac Rally Championship  Pendragon stages at Warcop training camp in Cumbria on Sunday August 26.They were Donald Bowness and navigator Paul Gribben in their Vauxhall Nova and Jamie Miller and Ian McCulloch in their Citroen C2R2Max. Both crews compete in the 1600 class.This was Jamie&#8217s second outing in the car.
